content:
Posted: September 30, 2014
												In Surgeon Simulator 2013 you control Nigel Burke, a guy who can't even tie his shoe laces without making "finger spaghetti" out of himself. Anyway, you control his fingers and thumb using the keyboard, which works well at simulating a hand. The controls can get a little frustrating, however I think that was a little on purpose. Now, most of you are all wondering the same question: Does it have a good story? Yes. It shows a man who poses a lack of hand motor skills and has a dream of becoming a surgeon, the best surgeon, but you are the only one who can fulfil his dream. The story and game play intertwine nicely and always makes you ask the same question: Was it worth it? As you stare down at the life insurance fee, was it worth it...? That aside, the game has three different types of surgery: Heart Transplant, Kidney Transplant and the Brain Transplant. They all are extremely fun and varied and include funny references, while you Tomahawk Chop someone in the skull. There is also a few secret levels, which I won't tell you about since they are...secret. Just go easy on the heavy (I've given my condolences to enough Team Fortress characters). In a nutshell, Surgeon Simulator controls well,  Has frustratingly-fun levels and even the starting menu provided for several minutes of fun. NOTE:  This is my first review, so I know it isn't that good, however I hope to get better as I write more.

number of helpful: 97 of 114 people (85%) found this review helpful38 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
												Most of us are well short of the level of education and subsequent anatomical knowledge required to successfully perform a heart transplant. Still, who wouldn't mind experiencing the awesome wave of heroic accomplishment that washes over a surgeon each time he or she saves a person's life? Surgeon Simulator 2013, a game from Bossa Studios, won't help you be a surgeon. It won't help you save lives, either. Hell, I'd even go as far as to say it has a negative influence on your personal knowledge of what invasive surgery actually entails. What it does do, almost in spite of itself, is haphazardly simulate the thrill of ripping a man's heart out of his chest and replacing it with another one.Surgeon Simulator 2013 replicates surgery the same way Enviro-Bear 2010 simulates a bear driving a car; with one hand and deliberately obtuse control. You play as Nigel Burke, or, more specifically, you play as Nigel Burke's left hand. Each of Nigel's fingers are controlled with your fingers on the A, W, E, and R keys, respectively, while Nigel's and your thumb is left to the space bar. Yes, that's completely insane, and yet also sort of logical position for your hand on a keyboard.Surgeon Simulator 2013's clumsy control is more of an endearing hook than a frustrating point of contention. It seems impossible, but, like rubbing your stomach and patting your head, an operational degree of control is gained with a bit of practice. Plopping Nigel’s hand down on a scalpel and watching him haphazardly pick it up like a cave man holding a pencil is both effectively hilarious and functionally acceptable. Hovering the hand over an artery and dropping it to replicate some sort of crude sawing motion looks absurd, but typically manages to get the job done. Playing Surgeon Simulator 2013 for a couple hours grants an almost expert level of control, but being a novice is almost more enjoyable simply because of how ridiculous everything appears when swinging Nigel’s dumb hand around the operating table.It helps that Surgeon Simulator 2013’s proposed method of surgery is almost completely unrealistic. Despite being mostly about goofs up to this point, there's a neat little game packed in Surgeon Simulator 2013. If you wreck Bob's guts too much he'll start bleeding, and if he bleeds out completely you'll murder the poor ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and fail the surgery.Spontaneity is perhaps Surgeon Simulator 2013's finest asset. Being physics-based game loaded with a ton of props, it's prone to numerous instances of accidental mishaps. Since Nigel's arms controls like your arm if it had been numb for three years, knocking all of the extraneous crap over on the operating table is a common occurrence. Likewise, accidentally dropping your scalpel, bone saw, or plastic spoon inside Bob's chest cavity is frequently unavoidable. From getting a scalpel lodged in your palm to accidentally administering hallucinogenic drugs on yourself, Surgeon Simulator 2013 is loaded with random and surprising tomfoolery.Obscene humor is the reason to play Surgeon Simulator 2013, and it delivers that asset in spades, but down the line it actually morphs into a legitimate challenge. After failing twenty or whatever times, I was sweating bullets the first time I managed to complete the kidney transplant. The sheer amount of things that could go wrong, not the mention the sloppy control, made for a true feeling of accomplishment upon completion. It's nothing like real surgery, obviously, but I did feel the overwhelming need to high five every one around and celebrate once I finally got it right.Half the fun is mentioning the premise of Surgeon Simulator 2013 to a buddy and then watching him or her come to grips with the outrageous task before them.And there you have it. Surgery Simulator 2013 is a joke, and its creators are well aware of that fact, but it’s effectively the best game about completing surgical procedures with a phantom limb ever made.

content:
Posted: April 10, 2014
												Surgeon Simulator is ridiculously stupid yet somehow manages to be frustratingly fun. Your role is simple. Play doctor and transplant specific organs without letting your patient die. Sounds complicated right? Well the game severely dumbs down the process effectively letting you rip out anything you don't need to focus on the task at hand.Learning the controls is actually half of the fun. You only get one hand in the game, but you have to control that one hand with two hands of your own using both the keyboard and mouse. The mouse moves your wrist and arm and the keyboard grasps your fingers to grab tools and organs. It's quite tricky to get the hang of because it just feels so unnatural and it can be quite a challenge to hold tools at just the right angle to make that precision cut.Although the title may give a false sense that it showcases some realism, there is no doubt that Surgeon Simulator is designed for purely amusement purposes only. And it certainly excels in the amusement category. An extremely original concept plus very innovative gameplay make this a game worth trying at least once.

Posted: November 28, 2013
												A hyper-realistic surgical procedure simulation program, likely used the world over to train medical professionals.Playing this intense game, you get put second-by-second in total control of a mans life.The real world physics and photo-realistic graphics, combined with the Oculus Rift support makes this an unforgettable experience, almost identical to performing real open heart surgery yourself.As such, it is a very gory game and should not be attempted or even purchased by the weak of stomach or those with a tremorous disposition.It is also impossibly difficult, requiring a stready hand, a sweaty brow and utmost focus. Do NOT play if alone, under the age of 18 or have not had 3 years in medical school beforehand. Highly difficult, very realistic, outstandingly educational.I look forward to future productions from this outstanding simulation company.

number of helpful: 84 of 101 people (83%) found this review helpful13 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 28, 2015
												Surgeon Simulator is a first person QWOP game. You take the role of a surgeon named Nigel Burke. Mouse movements control your doctor’s hand, up, down, left, right, and rotating. A, W, E, R and space bar are all used to control individual fingers on the hand, this is used to grasp the utensils, The game play consists of the player trying to complete a number of different operations on your patient, the first being something as simple as a heart transplant. Once completing the first operations, you then unlock different scenarios, such as ambulance operations, ad space operations, which incorporate bumping round tools and zero gravity, The graphics are nicely presented and everything looks clean and polished, I don't think photo realism graphics would be something I would be looking for in this type of game anyway. The soundtrack is mainly the general hospital/emergency theme tune the whole time, I had to turn it off after the first hour or two as it just grew very repetitive very fast, all of the sound effects in game of the grinding, sawing and squelching are all very nicely produced. This game is hard, like, hard as nails hard, I am nowhere near completing it, and I have played for almost eleven hours, your hands start to ache if you play any more than an hour due to the intense holding down of the buttons and thought that goes into picking up a single item, it is unbelievable, I did try out using a controller using Pinnacle Gaming Profile (quick shout out to them while I am at it), and this did make the controls a little easier to use, but it was still stupidly difficult.I haven't found any technical issues, I would think a potato could run Surgeon Simulator; it's a well optimized game.A lot of the time I spent on this was playing with friends, just playing around seeing how messed up we could get, and that's what this game is all about, just having a laugh and giggle, it's hard to sit down on your own for hours at a time on this game just because of how strenuous it is on your hand and thought process just to pick something up. But I do recommend that people pick it up, just for the novelty value and for some couch gaming with friends.If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up. You can also find more reviews over at http://www.completingthebackloggroup.com/

number of helpful: 82 of 100 people (82%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 11, 2013
												Long spoken of as myth, fairy-tale or merely the raving delusions of a mad man, an ancient and mysterious evil has awoken and proven itself a very real and dangerous threat to all in the once pleasant land of Infirmary. But there is yet hope as a band of unlikely heroes unite to vanquish this foe and send it back to the vile domain from whence it came. Play the roles of plucky Pinkie, the young but eager son of a blacksmith, Ring, the exiled princess trying to win back her rightful place as heir to the throne, the short-tempered Middle with a past shrouded in secrecy and an apparent score to settle, Thumb, the stoic and noble paladin sworn to defend the realm, and their brave leader Index, who together form the brotherhood of The Hand of Nigel, as they set forth on adventure in a world filled with peril at every turn. Face hideous, demented foes throughout the course of your journey such as the snake-like Intesties, the oozing Liveros, and the worst villains of them all, The Board of Medical Examiners. Lay siege to their fortress of bones, but choose your weapons careful, as only the right tools will grant you access to their grotesque dungeons. Mere tiny blades and cutting devices will ne'er be enough to pass, but with steadfast determination and a mighty hammer you will see your way through to the inner sanctum. Once inside be prepared to face the horrible wretches that lie in wait for you, the bosses within the bowels of each twisted lair, including Master Pump, The♥♥♥♥♥♥taker, and the most sickening of them all... Big Brain. Only when these are vanquished will you truly be able to call yourself the Hero of Infirmary and claim the hand of the fair maiden Trisha. It is not a quest for those faint of heart or lacking in skill or valour, but great rewards await any warrior brave enough to take on this challenge as you traverse the wastelands, do battle astride the back of high speed carriages, and even magically voyage through the cold, dark void of outer space on your intrepid excursions. Find glory and pass into legend, or succumb to the forces of evil and meet your doom, but whatever you do, tread carefully lest you summon the wrath of the greatest danger of all, the all-knowing, omnipresent... Bob.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2013
												I have no idea if you are going to like this game. It's a weird, hard to control, bizarre game. People compare it to QWOP and to the extent that it relies on playing twister with your fingers that's true, but it's much more than that. Each surgery is like a puzzle, trying to figure out which tools work and don't, finding the most efficient route through it. Achievements incentivize creative play. I mean, the most amazing thing about the game is that it exists at all, it's so absurd. But I think if you get past the initial curve you'll find a compelling score/time attack game.I'll also add that if you have people over to your house, non-gamers LOVE watching this. A casual hammer to the skull here, a drill dropped in a chest cavity there, accidentally throwing the replacement heart away. It's all good.You're looking at 8-10 hours for completion of every surgery with good scores, maybe 12-15 if you want to go to A++ on everything. The developers have also repeatedly updated the game with new free content, so I think it's fair to say that if you're the type that buys games to support a developer, this is a good choice.

content:
Posted: July 25, 2014
												Maybe? I would ultimately say no. It is about manipulating a hand in minute detail using overly-specific controls. To wit: you can rotate your wrist, raise and lower the arm, and contract each finger separately. This hand of yours, you use it to manipulate objects in your environment to remove internal organs and replace them with new ones. In the process, hilarity ensues.There is nothing wrong with this, and I actually do think the emergent comedy of my in-game physical ineptitude is amusing, it's just not that fun to play. A lot of trial and error as I try to figure out which awkwardly held item is the best one to use to remove X-bit of anatomy, then awkwardly moving the arm around to get the correct grip on the tool, then awkwardly hacking out the bit. A lot of awkward manipulations going on, and at some point I'll mess up, or hack at the wrong thing while trying to hack at the right one, and the patient will bleed out, and I'll have to do it all over again. I can see someone having fun with all this. Unfortunately, I'm just not that person.

number of helpful: 16 of 17 people (94%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 31, 2014
												The name should be «Mentally Handicapped Arm Simulator 2013». You control it via keyboard and mouse, rotating a hand, bending fingers and a wrist. In real life it takes a second to grab something, here it may take 30-60 seconds, in addition you may make a mess around. I laughed already at the main menu, which is part of the game, and I laughed out loud for the first 10 minutes of the surgery. Laughed like a kid. But then all the sandbox fun stops and you try to move on with the tasks. That's where it gets really annoying. It's both challenging and stupid, and I'm not eager for that kind of challenge. But I bet there's people out there who are. And you may be one of them.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												As an amateur home surgeon, performing surgery on myself and close relatives, I've always felt my field is given short shrift in the gaming diaspora. So naturally I was overjoyed when I discovered Surgeon Simulator 2013. Finally, an accurate portrayal of my day-to-day, and a chance to hone my skills. I used to be apprehensive about taking on those tricky triple heart bypasses in the zero gravity facility I maintain in my basement. But after just minutes with this highly realistic training tool, I feel like a veritable machine on the operating table! What's more, it turns out I didn't need my right arm anyway!It can get awfully dull down here. But now at least I've got the confidence to take my new-found expertise into the wider community, and it's all thanks to Surgeon Simulator 2013. Interested in the field? Don't waste time on worthless medical degrees or expensive bribes. Your one-stop solution is right here.

content:
Posted: June 12, 2015
												Surgeon Simulator, if I were to sum it up, is 20 minutes of hilarious insanity, followed by a few hours of frustration, mixed with the occasional, satisfying, successful procedures.     Surgeon Simulator is packed with hilarious moments of utter chaos and insanity, such as performing dental surgery with a hatchet, bonesaw, and pencil, or trying to figure out the hilariously awkward controls to perform simple tasks like picking up your phone, or putting a floppy disk in a computer. You have probably seen all that on You Tube.But after about 20 minutes (varies from person to person), but the chaos gets old really quickly. And then comes the frustration.     You'll be trying to actually finish a surgery, only to be constantly pestered by your character's inability to perform simple tasks, such as picking up items, cramming his hand into tight places, putting more than 20 centimeters between his hand and the patient, inability to peek around his arm, and last but not least his spontanious fits of cerebral palsy.      Which is to say that sometimes your character will fail to pick up items despite his hand being straight on top of them when you flex the fingers, the reach of your arm is so short you cannot reach the farthest edges of the operating table, and in surgeries where the patient is upright, you can barely get your hand over your patient's head, making it nigh impossible to avoid smacking your patient in the face with whatever you're wielding. Besides that, your arm will almost constantly be blocking the view of either your tool or the organ you're trying to sever, and you will constantly drop things despite having a firm grip on them.     These arduous controls are what make the game fun for the first twenty minutes of intentional chaos and carnage, but are also what makes the rest of the game time horrible, and filled with unintentional chaos and carnage.     It does have plenty of good humor, though. I particullalartly liked the TF2 easter egg.I have decided not to recommend it, but this is only because I would not recommend it at its normal price. I bought it during a sale, and that is probably the primary reason I am not overly disappointed with the game.     If you like chaos and mayhem and randomness, then you'll probably have a good time. If you like to get stuff done, then this is really, really not the game for you.

content:
Posted: April 2, 2016
												Beyond the absurdity and the humor, Surgeon Simulator can only offer frustration. Poor controls are taken as a core design philosophy and buttressed with any restrictive obstacle that came to mind. This is not the hilarious but humbling exercise of realizing how difficult complicated basic movement really is, this is a constant fight against a game that not only has to struggle to understand what the player wants it to do but also has trouble preventing objects from phasing in and out of each other. The lesson this game has to teach, what it demands of its players, is that they put aside the anger born of uncooperative controls to practice patience and precision in a world that has none. It's quite clever really. Shame all that's left to look back on is annoyance after annoyance, which increases level by level in the name of some sense of progression.

content:
Posted: May 11, 2015
												I played this game hoping to learn something about surgery. I started playing, had myself having difficulties with controlling the left hand and found out that I won't really learn much about this field.I went on playing for a few more hours for some days and I enjoyed having control over Nigel's left hand. There are a lot of stupid things that you can do with the patient and I found both playing around with the patient and completing each of the surgical operations really enjoyable.Barnardshire had a couple of surgery options available. Unfortunately Bob had a lot of ailments which left him no choice but to have heart, kidney, and brain transplant. As Nigel, you'll have to do all the operations in different environments. As you go on and become more dexterous you can make Nigel become practically licensed. I had the most difficulty getting A++ doing the brain transplant inside an ambulance, paying attention to what happens in the environment can really help in making Nigel the best surgeon in the world. If you work hard you can even do your surgical maneuvers in outer space, who knows what may happen when things float all over the place?I am almost done with what the base game offers and I am looking forward to getting the Anniversary Edition Content for the eye & teeth operations plus the corridor environment.

number of helpful: 16 of 21 people (76%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 16, 2015
												Intro:I feel that the main goal of Bossa Studios for the original game, was to get a quick laugh from the audience and maybe make some money off of it, I feel the same for this version. Ask anybody that owns it about why they bought the game and they will most likley say "Because it looked funny". I think the only reason you would buy this game is due to the fact that it looked freaking hillarious to see a scalpel jammed into some poor man's eye. I mean, who really want's to buy this for the pure challenge of preforming sugery on a patient? I would assume you want to buy this as an escape from the daily life, to the inner realms of video games where everything that happens is supposed to be a fun experience, and I think it does this fairly well.Gameplay:I think that the gameplay is pretty hard, and the fact that it is hard is just the point of the game. The devs as gamers thought about the most annoying things you could implement, and afterward implemented them. I think that the devs never expected this to be a really good game that people played and speedran just due to the fact that it was only intended as a quick laugh and nothing more. When it comes to the Pros and the Cons of the game I don't like adressing them just due to the fact that as previously stated, the cons were intended for the end product long before the release of the game. I can't judge the gameplay of this as it really depends on your sense of humor and expectations of what a game should be.Conclusion:Since this game was mainly to make a funny statement about something, I don't feel like you should even consider playing it like a real video game, but to play it as a form of comedy that you may come back to after a hard day of work. To actually play it as a fully fledged video game is just foolhardy, and if you want a FAIR challenging experience, I wouldn't really recommend it in any way shape or form. 100%ing this thing was really pointless in the whole scheme of things, and in all honesty it ruined the experience of ever playing a game like it again. I think if it's on sale (which it usally is) go for it, there is no crime in laughing at a fake man's misery, or doing psychologically questionable things to his organs, however, I urge you to never ever play it like a real game, but to only ever play it as a silly satire on the "Simulation" genre of today...Side Note: If I could give this a "Mixed" or "So-So" review I would use that instead, but alas I am stuck with the current steam system of reviewing something.

number of helpful: 16 of 24 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 23, 2014
												"HURP DE DURR IMMA BAD SURGEON!!1" the crowing of YouTubers continues.  You wanna know why this game is so popular?  It's because of all those Million+ viewed videos of people screaming in frustration as they try to hack past a sternum and kill their patients.  It's another game like 'I Wanna Be The Guy', but the controls are purposefully horrible instead of being purposefully designed to kill you every second.This isn't a game you play for good fun or trying to be a real surgeon.  Surgeon Simulator 2013 is a joke app made by a bunch of chuckle ♥♥♥♥s in a very short time and is kind of a hollow gimmick once you get past the awful controls.The hand has a VERY limited range of motion, it can't turn any objects to any kind of natural position for precision, it's sluggish like you're moving through molasses, the hand lags a half second behind the mouse, and it's incredibly hard to grasp anything in your fingers without stuff flying all over the place and putting them in a worse position or out of reach.  (My arm actually started getting tired from trying to meanuever the mouse so much.)  This thing will be what you will control the entire game with from the Menu screen to the dozen or so surgeries you'll have.You also have to do it under a time limit as the more you cut and crush drains your patient of blood and you'll very soon have a countdown timer (blood loss) till the patient dies.  Get ready to start pulling your hair out as this exercise in frustration will leave you cursing at the screen for a long time like why the god damned hand doesn't grasp anything properly.I recommend looking through the Diskettes on the main menu that you can pop into the Commodore computer.  They show you shortcuts on how to more effectively cut the tiny arteries, scooping intestines, etc.There's not much content outside of the bare stages where instruments are strewn about.  You're a single surgeon inside an operating chamber and you have to perform a transplant of some kind in several different environments.  Heart, kidneys, and brains in a surgeon's ward, ambulance, and space.  There's a Team Fortress 2 level that's ripped from the Meet The Medic trailer and an alien autopsy.  That's it.  There's nothing else to do except try to go for a highscore, but it's worthless.  Once you're done, you'll probably want to quit the game and uninstall it.I get the "joke" of what this game is.  It's like a trainwreck made of organs and flying utensils, but the controls aren't worth it.  Avoid this crap.

												I, at one time, might have discounted or otherwise insulted this game for being gimmicky and ironic, in private, to as many people as I could rant to.  Do not vote for this game, I said, for it is just monkey cheese nonsense being sold to dumb internet people.  But somewhere between not enjoying the demo and receiving the full version, this game grabbed me between it's shaky noodly fingers.  Between the awkward controls and the wonky physics is a game that actually works under it's own weird set of rules.  Sure you might drop a fresh organ or two on the floor, or lose a couple out of the back of a moving ambulance, and oftentimes it won't be your fault, but at the same time you'll likely just nod your head and realize that it's just another facet of the game and reload, ready and eager to take another crack at Bob's insides (was that one entire sentence?)Point being, this game is a celebration of the human condition, and a real testament to courage and the power to overcome obstacles that seem impossible.  You'll laugh, you'll cry, you'll make your janitorial staff quit out of protest, but most importantly you'll learn to love and live.  And harvest organs.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2014
												Surgeon Simulator 2013 is a surgical simulation game.The controls are suitable rudimentary. You use three keys to flex your fingers, and spacebar for the thumb. Left click can be used to move the arm up and down, while holding down the right button controls the rotations. There are items which, when you grasp near them, sort of “stick” to your fingers.The amount of content in the game is a little sparse, you can finish everything it has to offer in a couple hours. There are 3 main procedures, 3 variants to these operations, and 2 extra missions. After you have completed all of these there is only the fun of goofing around with the game to add to play time.There are also several bugs, like the hand got stuck in the table and you have to restart the operation. Sometimes the syringe does not work. Also a frustrating thing is that if an item falls a little too far on the table, you have to restart, because you can not reach it anymore.Surgeon Simulator 2013 is not a brilliant game, but a brilliant joke, in the form of a game.Sounds 5/10Graphics 5/10Gameplay 4/10Atmosphere 6/10If you liked my review, please feel free to follow me and/or my curator group:http://steamcommunity.com/id/Ov3RT4K3R/myworkshopfiles/?section=guideshttp://steamcommunity.com/groups/orcollective#curationAlso feel free to check out my YouTube Channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC83DYCmrWfl9ttrhX54jmWA

number of helpful: 11 of 16 people (69%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 16, 2014
												You play as a butcher who pretends to be a surgeon, but not an ordinary surgeon, it's a surgeon that has only one hand, wears no gloves and has the manual dexterity of a 3 year old kid!PROS:- You may learn something about the position of your guts;- You'll have an idea about how it feels to control a mechanical hand, like those used by people who had an amputed arm. But worse;- You may fulfill your sadistic instincts by killing your patients with surgical tools;- You may hit yourself with your own anesthesia syringe, which will make your vision psychodelic.CONS:- Controls are awful, VERY awful. Five keys on the keyboard control the closing of your fingers and the mouse will control the movement of your hand, just like a remote-controlled robotic hand would be;- There's no automatic adjustment of the objects to your hand, which means that you'll pick up objects any way you can, they will never be in the right position and will easily fall from your hand, again similar to a mechanical hand;- Your arm is always in the same horizontal position and will get in the way often;- If you drop something on the far corner of the table or let it fall to the ground you can't reach it anymore, it's lost forever;- It's too difficult to succeed, but possible if you try very, very hard and have a lot of patience (I don't);- Your patients are completely sedated and won't react to your sadism in case you like this kind of thing;- Your patients basically die by blood loss (there's a blood counter measuring how near it is to death), so whatever you do will have the same effect. The only difference is the speed of bleeding.CONCLUSION:Initiallly fun because of the absurdities, but infuriating thereafter. I can't recommend.

content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
												7th of February 2016:To everyone who worked on this game: nice try, but go ♥♥♥♥ yourself with a car, die a horrible and painful death and rot in a sewer. Why?First have a look at this video: 


YouTube™ Video: Surgeon Simulator in a nutshell 

			Views: 1,190		

			Sorry for the beeping sound, had my mic still enabled and it kinda does that... So anyway, holy♥♥♥♥♥♥how buggy and annoying a game can be, especially when going for the achievements!		

Next, let me explain some of the things about this game:1) Glitchy collision models. Your hand and instruments will always keep getting clipped inside something or something gets stuck inside your hand or between your fingers. VERY frustrating when going for the challenges/achievements.2) Operations are 50% luck when it comes to finding the right spot where to cut. You can easily spend several minutes trying to find the spot you need to cut to proceed. Most frustrating being the eye transplants, where you need to stab Bob in both eyes with a scapel for example, but good ♥♥♥♥ing luck trying to get it in the eye, since it's apparently random when it decides to go in. The angle, force, position of the eye, NOTHING like that matters. The scapel goes in when it wants because ♥♥♥♥ the player. And don't even get me started with the Corridor -operations, where the RNG decides what you get next as random trolleys pass by, which BTW do NOT respawn the instruments that have fallen off. Good luck if they spawn clipping inside eachother and thus just exploding everywhere!3) Speaking operations and challenges, how can the Hell can you still have a game with such glitchy achievements? 180 spoon flip? Nah, barely 20 degrees did it for me. And don't even get me started on the achievements that fail to realize that you've completed them. And the biggest insult in challenges: "I can see miles... per hour." First the description: "Complete the eye transplant in an ambulance in 1 minute and 60 seconds." What the ♥♥♥♥ even is that? Did the devs REALLY fail with even a simple task of writing a DESCRIPTION?! If they can ♥♥♥♥ up even a simple description then how can they program the challenges, let alone an entire game properly?!I could go on with the flaws this game has, but I don't think the devs deserve the feedback.I will complete this game to show that I did manage to beat this piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥ but NEVER expect me to buy a single game from Bossa Studios EVER AGAIN!YOU WILL NOT DEFEAT ME WITH YOUR LACKING PROGRAMMING!EDIT----------9th of February 2016:Came back to tell you that I have now reached 100% completion of this pile of junk. And let me tell you people, the inaccuracies are everywhere, especially in the Alien Operations! I also realized how much this game relied on YouTubers by adding achievements and alien organs after them. Yeah nice marketing trick you got there: make an organ or achievement after a YouTuber to have them play the game and get free advertisement.But let me tell you people, the amount of relief when I saw the last achievemnt pop up and then hitting "Delete Local Content" was much better than actually playing this game.Tata and good ♥♥♥♥ing riddanceEDIT----------4th of July 2016:I came back to write some more after you filthy "FUNNY" developers decided to add more achievements to this piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥excuse for a functioning game.You did it again. You ♥♥♥♥S did it AGAIN! You added some "FUNNY" ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t but you couldn't have been bothered to test it to make sure that works properly!You people STILL haven't fixed ANY of the issues, you've only added some! Look at the "Small Loan From My Father" -achievement. $1M in a medical bill? Okay, seems easy enough, right? ♥♥♥♥ YOU! What you need to do to get this achievement is to basically use a glitched and inconsistent mechanic because you CANNOT do this legitimately! I even red some forum threads that this is a bug. Okay, so you're working on it? How the ♥♥♥♥ is it taking a MONTH already to fix it?!♥♥♥♥ you then, I will play your ♥♥♥♥♥♥ piece of cancer of a game to get back the 100% completion.You are all a bunch of filthy and pathetic excuses for game developers.EDIT----------14th of August 2016:IN! YOUR! ♥♥♥♥ING! FACE!It took me a month to get the Small Loan achievement but I DID get it and now I'm back to 100% completion!And what REALLY shined through that time was the amount of♥♥♥♥♥♥Bossa passes through. The idea of the achievement isn't that bad, but when you basically have to glitch your way to the achievement because you CAN'T do it what feels like a sensible way. Because apparently SOMEONE at Bossa thought that it was a good idea to give more money for the hospital bill the harder you hit Trump, while it's already very easy to glitch your tools inside the models. No, not just loodging your tools in the ribcage, I'm talking about an AXE getting stuck INSIDE Trump's face  when you try piling up some more money.But still, once again, I have BEATEN your "game" and I am DONE with this♥♥♥♥♥♥ AGAIN."Delete Local Content?" Yes please.

												Instruction manual to successful surgery:1) Stab the patient in his throat to prevent him from breathing. Breathing can cause issues with surgery.2) Reach your hand inside his chest and yank his heart out.3) Since their is no buget to replace it with a new one, insert a soda can.4) If the surgery still doesn't say "success," it is glitching. Stab the patient in the chest with your drill to get it running smoothly again.After these steps, you should have completed a successful surgery.

content:
Posted: September 12, 2016
												I bought this game on a steam discounts, at autumn. And it was my first simulator I've ever played.For the first time, this game doesn't look like something big. It was older versions of surgeries with a small amount of operations. So I played a bit, and forgot about it. But then DLC comes out, I found, what the game got a big overhaul, and since I want to get 100% achievements in a game, I guess I should give it a try, and wasn't dissapointed.What can I say something else? Well, about some parts, like graphics or stuff. Graphics are good, physical part is fine (but sometimes physics are testing your patience), music is amazing. Something bad about this game? Well, if you are going to achieve 100%, this will gonna test your nerves so badly, because you need to be fast with a bit bad controls. Speaking of controls, you can't play this game for too long, because with default controls, you hand will be tired in 30 mins. I recommend you do some break after some surgeries. Well, I have nothing to say anything more.I definitelty recommend this game, if you want a simulator, what gives you a challenge. And also, to have a full experience of this game, grab a DLC.P.S Sorry, if I messed up, somewhere, with English.

												You can murder your patient with a tomahawk,or even a laser cutter.10/10OK,here's the serious review :Pros :+ Funny and silly gameplay+ Challenging and has a replay value+ Team Fortress 2 heart transplant and Alien surgery available+ Strange but fun control system+ Worth the price.In fact,it's pretty cheap for the amount of fun you'll get.Cons :- Almost impossible for me to solve each surgery without watching YouTube for solutions- Unrealistic animations.They should add effects if we slashed Bob (your patient)'s face with tomahawk or burn his face with a laser cutter rather than just blood squirting out of nowhere.- Single player only.It would be fun if they add co op with two hands.I saw someone played co op on youtube,though.Not sure how did they do it.

Posted: February 2, 2014
												This game is fantastic for someone who recently lost his job, life, and family due to a malpractice case. I have never played a simulation game that perfectly gives you an experience of being a surgeon. I operated exactly like the in-game doctor, and that's why I lost everything. My wife doesn't talk to me, my kids pretend like I don't exist, and I wasted 7 years of my life in med school, only to lose my job as well. At least I still have Surgeon Simulator 2013.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												Silly, silly, silly. This game is an incredible amount of fun, though if you're squeamish at the prospect of flying digital guts and blood...well why are you looking at this game?But in all seriousness, the style is smooth and visually grabbing, the controls only mildly frustrating when you're on a time crunch (Use two hands, Nigel!), and the enjoyment factor is up to extremely satisfying. My favorite bit is that it even includes a side mission related to my favorite game Team Fortress 2, which if you haven't played, do. The menu is also them most uniquely extensive I've seen, and so much fun to interact with. Warning: You may become so distracted you forget there's an actual game attached.The only time Surgeon Simulator has frustrated me was when I was going for a couple of especially difficult achievements, but even then I still liked it. I mention this because if you have patience issues, you may find less enjoyment in it than I did, but I'd still urge anyone to try this game.

Posted: July 9, 2014
												Do you want to become a professional surgeon? Do you want to pursue a career in medicine? If yes then this is the game for you! A great ‘simulation’ game where a convenient hammer is always lying around and you can tear out every organ in the body and the patient is somehow miraculously alive. At first the controls are a bit hard to grasp but with a little practice you will be up and preforming heart transplants within minutes. Definitely a game worth getting and is really worth the £6.99 or $10 and even less on sale. I would give it a      9 / 10, worth the buy.

content:
Posted: August 11, 2013
												This is fun, and very challenging game. However, don't be fooled by the word 'Simulator' in the title. This game 'simulates' surgery in much the same way that the old board game 'Operation' does. You play the game by manipulating a single hand, and then using tools laid out around you to do the operations. Controlling the hand is difficult at first, but you get accustomed to it with time.If you ever wanted to attempt a brain transplant in the back of a moving ambulance, play this.

content:
Posted: February 8, 2014
												THIS GAME IS SO DAMN FRUSTRATING!I love this funny, surgeon simulation game. You have a patient to operate on named, 'Bob', with 5600ml of blood, and you have a series of tools. Such as, hammers, saws, knives, etc. You can basically beat the crap into Bob for fun and achievements.The first level area is in a basic surgery room, with the heart transplant, kidney transplant and brain transplant. The second level area is in a moving ambulance (VERY FRUSTRATING) you have the same procedures as level one.The third level area is SO DAMN FRUSTRATING. You are in SPACE in a low earth orbit (LEO) with floating tools.The last level area is operating on an alien in an unknown region of space. It is entertaining. I recommend this game.

Posted: February 8, 2014
												THIS GAME IS SO DAMN FRUSTRATING!I love this funny, surgeon simulation game. You have a patient to operate on named, 'Bob', with 5600ml of blood, and you have a series of tools. Such as, hammers, saws, knives, etc. You can basically beat the crap into Bob for fun and achievements.The first level area is in a basic surgery room, with the heart transplant, kidney transplant and brain transplant. The second level area is in a moving ambulance (VERY FRUSTRATING) you have the same procedures as level one.The third level area is SO DAMN FRUSTRATING. You are in SPACE in a low earth orbit (LEO) with floating tools.The last level area is operating on an alien in an unknown region of space. It is entertaining. I recommend this game.

content:
Posted: July 15, 2016
Product received for free
Will It Run?I have only ever written a review for Steam games that are exceptionally easy to run on almost any computer. As for myself I can hardly run Minecraft but I have no problem running Surgeon Simulator. Even on max quality settings Learning CurveGame just comes with practice but then again it isn't skill based at all. I would compare it to a standard phone game it only gets easier by playing over, and over again.About The GameIn case you haven't noticed from the game trailer or a video of this games gameplay. It's not anywhere close to being a Surgeon Simulator. In this game, you have to grab any object around you that looks decently sharp and attempt to tear and rip out your patience organs until you have reached whichever organ you are preforming a transplant on. At that point, if it were a heart transplant for example. You would have to rip out the heart and simply drop a new clean healthy one in its place. Not saying this game is bad but I to clarify for the few people who think its an actual surgeon simulation.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 5, 2015
												Hilarious and Fun!The best way to describe this game.The greatest streght of this game, just like "Goat Simulator" is that it goes beyond the initial "Laugh -Spoof Factor" and actually offers a challenging and intense game.Surgeon Simulator puts you in the hand (literally) of a surgeon, ready to operate some rather unlucky patients.The operations are rather absurd (like brain transplants and such) and the intentionally "random" physics make everything so much fun to play!If you want to you can ignore the mission goals to "annoy" (or brutally murder) your patient and the tools you use to "operate" surely are inappropriate...Saws, Lasers, Hammers ecc...it's pure madness.Highly recommended game.Pros:- Fun to play- Hilarious- Many collateral activities (starting from the menu itself)- Many easter eggs and secrets- Challenging (in a good way)- Fun to play even when creating a senseless mess.Cons:- Only 3 types of operations (remixed in very different ways, though)To Keep in Mind:- The controls are very hard to get used to and disorienting, for the first hour...but after a while you grow accustomed to them and actually appreciate how they work.

content:
Posted: November 15, 2014
												If I could have any profession, ignoring all college costs and other ties, I would want to be a trauma surgeon. This is as close as I'm getting. And sure it's not exactly how surgeory is, like you don't use a ball pein hammer to knock teeth out! You use a claw hammer, we all know that. But it still makes you feel the power a surgeon must feel, performing on this obviously sick Bob, who's in for every operation known to man. Seriously, if you need a new heart, kidney, brain, and eyes then you should probably just pull the plug.This game is tough to play if you have a laptop, so make sure you have a mouse too if you plan on buying.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2015
												A very difficult but fun and unique game that requires you to be calm and collected, especially when well.. you get high. You have to learn to be precise in controlling your virtual hand to for instance poke out eyeballs with pencils or place kidneys in their specific gaps (worst thing in the world). Alternatively you can bash your patient's head with fire extinguishers and electrocute yourself. This game is filled with dozens of tiny secrets and unfortunetly if you want a 100% achievement completion, you will have to look things up. This game isn't perfect, there aren't many levels - only 5 basic types of surgeries in a couple of settings. I hope in the future some DLCs will be released. I recommend purchasing this game when it's on a sale.

number of helpful: 6 of 10 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
												Truly, a real indie game.This game lets you be a doctor, yes, a ♥♥♥♥ing doctor, without needing to study.You can maul your patient or you can heal him, both options are funny and cool as well.The game includes secret areas, secret pacients, different kind of surgeries in more than 4 different places.About the gameplay, basically you're a hand, your job is to move this hand and TRY to manipulate the tools to perform the surgery (or not). When you press the keys you really think that you're, in fact, the hand that performs the surgery. The funniest part of the game is trying to use the tools, maybe if you watch a gameplay You will probably say: "Seems easy, I don't know how this idiot can't use a drill", well It is not so easy as it looks.The idea of the game is not "have a good game story", It would be most like: "There you have, a human being, kill or try to heal him, good luck".It combines a hilarious theme and the seriousness of a surgery, having as a result this masterpiece. That's what makes this game one of the best inde games that I've ever played.9/10

content:
Posted: July 18, 2014
												Do not buy this game. I'm still stuck on the first task: controlling the damn thing. Before I'm told to get better at it, let me say this. This game is very similar to QWOP, as in the controls are meant to be very difficult and the game is not meant to be taken seriously. However, QWOP is free. This is $9.99. I bought Bastion, one of the best games ever made, in sale for about $2.00 (I can't remember the exact price. Sue me). Speaking of the controls, the difficulty here is more artificial than anything else. Let's compare this difficulty to another difficult game- Super Meat Boy. I think JonTron says it best: "[It's] ball-renchingly difficult, but you know what? The controls are so tight that if you mess up, it's entirely on you, and that feels good. It's great. Difficulty isn't the problem. Cheapness is." Say you're doing the heart transplant and the heart gets stuck in the ribcage. Cheapness. That's one word that actually sums this game up pretty well. Except for the price tag compared to the quality of the game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 9, 2014
												Ah yes, Surgeon Simulator 2013. There's a reason why it is NOT called Surgery Simulator, mainly because the operations in this game is extremely wacky and way off the standard protocol. (Surgery without gloves? Blasphemy!)You control a faceless surgeon who apparently has only one hand. (Which might also be the reason why he isn't wearing gloves, because how on Earth would someone put on gloves with only one hand without assistance from others?) Operations include heart transplant, double kidney transplant and brain surgery (which are the only ones I've unlocked so far, I hear there are secret missions that can be unlocked besides the TF2 crossover). Each operation can be repeated in a different setting other than the usual operating theatre, such as in a speeding ambulance and in a zero gravity environment. The controls are.......unique, as the keys are mapped according to which finger is used to tap each key. This means you have full finger control (finger gestures abound). But, full control does not mean simplicity, as you have to control the wrist and arm movements with the mouse. Therefore, to say the very least, the controls are very tricky, but once you have played several sessions you'll have some degree of mastery with it. Overall, it is a game with a quite steep learning curve, but the satisfaction gained when completing an operation is immense. 8 out of 10.

content:
Posted: January 7, 2014
												It seems like one of those games where the controls are so awfully weird, it's there just to screw around and try to do it. But the cool thing is, once you get used to the controls, you can actually try and do procedures as quick as possible.It's nice use of AWER and Space actually feel pretty comfortable and better than something like QWOP. You have a grading system that grades your performance based on how much blood was lost, and how fast you did it. This offers up the way to figure out what tools to use, and when to use 'em. For what music there is, it's nice background noise too. The Team Fortress 2 DLC was a very nice addition, and it makes me think this game also has pretty good DLC potential.

content:
Posted: August 28, 2013
												I remember being pretty confused by this game when I first saw it on Rage Quit. Was it trying to be sincere and doing a horrible job at it, or are the difficult controls a part of the joke? Thankfully it's the latter. This isn't surgery like a true surgeon would do... it's more like what I imagine an alien were to do if it found out its pet human needed a new organ. Just start jamming tools in there, removing everything that's in the way, then casually putting a new organ where the old one was. Done and done.If you love dark humor and a serious challenge, pick this game up.

content:
Posted: July 11, 2014
												Hello Ladies and Gentlemen and welcome to my review of Surgeon Simulator! in this cartoon style simulation game you play as the worst surgeon ever hired as you attempt to give several transplants and hope your paitents die so they can't sue you for malpractice.pros+Very creative take using a first person perspective to desimate your pateints and then lazily toss a organ inside of them!+The Ambluance levels are very creative thought frustrating to watch the transplant organ fly out the back once you hit a bump in the road+Tf2 inspired Dlc for free where you operate on heavy!?cons-Sometimes the controls are a little too frustrating for me -the lack of other surgeons in the room seems rathe odd for me considering I've been to a actually surgery and watch professional surgeons operate with a teamSo in the long run this game is a blast that I deffinatly reccomend buying and give a it a juicy score of 8.5/10.So heres to killing another paitent and never being sued!

content:
Posted: January 27, 2014
												The future of robotic surgery is closer than we think and this game is a tongue-in-cheek take on how tough it actually is to do.  For some people, it will be a fun challenge to grasp the controls and then acclimate them to the environments outside the operating room.  This game is not for everyone, though, so if you feel like you are playing QWOP: You Are Not Alone and The Truth is Out There......in Medical School and Residency, I mean, where actual doctors learn that stuff.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 13, 2013
												I was watching some of the major youtubers play this while it was in the beta. I found it quite trivial thinking it'd be like another generic simulator game, being fun at first and getting boring later. That had apparently not become the problem. I had bought this game when it first came out. It was at $15 and I thought to myself, "Wow, that's bloody expensive! This better be worth it.", and ever since that day it had been the best $15 I've ever spent. This gave me hours of enjoyment and something to relax with even though it may cause a lot of frustration and anger, it's quite relaxing knowing that you go in without any sense of wanting to complete the game for the story (since it has no story). The game is best played in company of others, while others may either see you fail the operation or complete it, it will either make them all laugh or praise you as "THE GOD OF SURGERY!". Watching Rooster Teeth's Michael and Gavin play the game together had given me an idea, playing the game with 2 players where 1 controls the fingers and the other controls the arm would make for a great party game or challenge. As it proves the synchroniation between 2 people for the greater humor or the professionality of the pair.With everything said, I would recommend this game to all people who are looking for a game to enjoy with friends and company of other people.

content:
Posted: September 11, 2014
												I love this game. Sugeon Simulatory 2013 is a hyperrealistic simulation experience that will inspire and train a new generation of physicians. I wouldn't be surpised if it also paves the way for alternative forms of surgery by people not classically seen as qualified. This game teaches us just how safe and easy performing surgery really can be. Vital signs? Anesthesiologists? Left hands? Unnecessary As an infectious particle, I have spent hours playing this game in order to discover new aveneues of infection to explore. The prospects expand every time I play the game, and I always await new downloadable content to expand my repertoire. Please play this game. Our very future depends on it.

												Hello Ladies and Gentlemen and welcome to my review of Surgeon Simulator! in this cartoon style simulation game you play as the worst surgeon ever hired as you attempt to give several transplants and hope your paitents die so they can't sue you for malpractice.pros+Very creative take using a first person perspective to desimate your pateints and then lazily toss a organ inside of them!+The Ambluance levels are very creative thought frustrating to watch the transplant organ fly out the back once you hit a bump in the road+Tf2 inspired Dlc for free where you operate on heavy!?cons-Sometimes the controls are a little too frustrating for me -the lack of other surgeons in the room seems rathe odd for me considering I've been to a actually surgery and watch professional surgeons operate with a teamSo in the long run this game is a blast that I deffinatly reccomend buying and give a it a juicy score of 8.5/10.So heres to killing another paitent and never being sued!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												On first glance appearing as a badly thrown together physics game that simply doesn't work the game will for most people suddenly reveal its genius after significant trial and error.All of a sudden you start noticing the absurd british humour, the subtle (Or not so subtle) political commentary on a view of the British national health service and you start to understand just how the game works and start becoming good at it. To the point where your not just trying to accomplish a heart surgery in the back of a moving ambulance, your seeing how quickly you can do it, if you can do it using only a fire extinguisher and a pair of scissors. Your seeing exactly how much crap you can place in the chest cavity of a patient mid operation and trying desperately to pry a kidney out from some ribs using a plastic spoon.There are plenty of frustrations, due to a niave expectation of how the game 'should' play to the occasional physics bug that can cause your hands or a scapel to get stuck in awkward situations (between ribs, in a fridge [Yes, there is a firdge] etc). Rising above these frustrations and learning from is key to getting the best from this game.This is no game of the year. But it is suprisingly intelligent and funny. Frankly if you don't have it, your missing out on something most people don't encounter very often. A new experience.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2013
												A bloody good time, the silly physics and complex controls add to the fun... if you find shoving power drills & orange soda bottles where they don't belong to be "fun".If you are studying to be a doctor & are looking for ways to practice surgery, then get off of Steam and get back to your Med School HW.  The content here isn't the most accurate when portraying organ transplants, and you won't be using your right hand solely for motion & your left hand solely for gripping in real surgery, let alone perform transplants in both a hospital & ambulance setting.All in all, if you want some silly fun turning an unconscious person into a corpse, go ahead with Surgeon Simulator 2013.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 10, 2015
												+ Sillyness+ Lots of easter eggs and fun details.- Tools being unreachable only due to limitations on how far your hand can move 'up'- Minor thing: wish you had slight more control over your head/camera posistion sometimes.  Even something simple like a 'tilt' so you can see what you are doing a little better.I wasn't expecting this.  You know what a baby looks like playing with toys.  They'll take a toy and very stiff-armedly bang away on something trying to replicate what they've seen an adult do while giggling or something.  That is essentially what this feels like.  You are in the shoes of a half mad-doctor, half man-child with little to no fine motor skills.Trying to perform surgery with controls this limited can certainly be frustrating at times, but at the same time, it's what provides a lot of the humor and ridiculousness to what you are doing.  If you had perfect controls the game would not work the same way.  Flailing around an arm and accidentally dropping a power drill into someones chest cavity while trying to do a heart transplant in the back of a moving ambulance is all part of the charm of the game.There is plenty of interactive small details to find and play with.  Even in your office.  Like a little playground, all this little stuff adds up to make a fun experience.  Plenty of subtle things like you'd find sprinkled into a Valve or Blizzard game.  It's been a long time since a game made me crack a smile.Don't be put off by the odd controls, once you get a little practice with them you'll be able to do what you intend to do (relatively speaking).  The awkwardness and sillyness they provide is part of the game.Recommended if you have a little patience and want to have a good time for a few hours.  And there is plenty more to do if you want to explore and try to get every little thing done.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 19, 2016
												I bought this game immediately after i saw the new Trump DLC and Discount, i thought "Yea, why not, must be hilarious". For a buck game, really worth your whileIf you're up for cheese and humors, go for itif you have haemophobia,then i'll suggest leave it.The game is pretty simple in idea but very entertaining as a flying hippo(also, guys... don't take this too seriously. It's not what you're looking for if you want to be a doctor, go take a real class)Pros:+Very funny to mess with +Bob has many diseases (which means many variety of surgery)+Tons of levels and difficulty+Feels like a real surgery (it's a simulator, duh)+Feels very british! (better if they had added Tea)+Awesome graphics @ glorious 60FPS [PC Master Race]Cons:-Somewhen the game feels glitchy and minor bugs also present (visit my screenshots for proof)-if you're uneasy with rage quitting, forget the game (some levels like the space and ambulance really takes my time)-If you drop your tools/ organs to right below you hand, that's it. No retrieving it.So, i'll say a yes for a game with many fun features (TF2 surgery is the best part, wait...) go thumbs up for this review so Bob doesn't have any diseases in the future.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2016
												I bought this game immediately after i saw the new Trump DLC and Discount, i thought "Yea, why not, must be hilarious". For a buck game, really worth your whileIf you're up for cheese and humors, go for itif you have haemophobia,then i'll suggest leave it.The game is pretty simple in idea but very entertaining as a flying hippo(also, guys... don't take this too seriously. It's not what you're looking for if you want to be a doctor, go take a real class)Pros:+Very funny to mess with +Bob has many diseases (which means many variety of surgery)+Tons of levels and difficulty+Feels like a real surgery (it's a simulator, duh)+Feels very british! (better if they had added Tea)+Awesome graphics @ glorious 60FPS [PC Master Race]Cons:-Somewhen the game feels glitchy and minor bugs also present (visit my screenshots for proof)-if you're uneasy with rage quitting, forget the game (some levels like the space and ambulance really takes my time)-If you drop your tools/ organs to right below you hand, that's it. No retrieving it.So, i'll say a yes for a game with many fun features (TF2 surgery is the best part, wait...) go thumbs up for this review so Bob doesn't have any diseases in the future.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
"The darkest and the most disturbing video game i ever played in my life"You play as Arthur Fischer (aka. Nigel Burke), a famous surgeon in Sao Paulo, Brazil.Who secretly work for the black market organ theft ring.Short story, he was a surgeon who secretly harvested human organs from the captured citizens from the favelas (slum area).The first mission is simple, you learn the basic how to harvest organs from a living person.But the second mission, Nigel have to do the surgery in the back of a moving van while getting chased by the police.and the third one (jumped the shark), Nigel must harvest Chris Hadfield's organs in space.Nonetheless, still a very great game, and a slightly more refreshing experience in the genre

Posted: March 25, 2016
												Have you ever wanted to throw someone's organs at them while they are asleep?What about cut someone's brain stem by throwing an axe at it?Or conduct eye surgery by electrocuting yourself and smacking them around with a hammer?In all seriousness this game is a lot of fun. It takes a bit of getting used to and the controls can be infuriating at first but it is definitely worth playing. Completing the basic surgeries is ok but the part that makes this game shine is when you start going for the surgery achievements. I would buy this game again at full price in a heart beat, If you can get it on sale even better.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												Welcome to Surgeon Simulator 2013, where you get to step into the shoes of our protagonist, a (rather clumsy) surgeon. As the name suggests, you get to be a surgeon in-game and you can perform operations of varying degrees of difficulty. I will give in-depth details below, based on what I have garnered from my playtime:The game is very open-ended. The only objective you have is to perform the surgery without killing off your patient (read: bleeding him to death). There are a variety of tools available and you can generally use most of them to achieve your goal. There is, of course a best possible way to achieve something and a worst possible way but hey, it's just a game.Since there is no actual science involved, the surgeries in themselves are hilarious and it just results in hours and hours of fun; also, I am pretty sure brain transplants aren't possible yet. The absence of any real science gives a humorous edge to the game.Another thing I really enjoyed was the part where I could perform the uber-heart transplant (is that what it's called?) on the Heavy weapons guy (you play as the Medic from TF2). It was extremely hilarious and reminded me of ye olde TF2 trailer, and playing it was like a reward for all the effort it took to put the VHS tape into the damn machine.The controls were really awkward (A-W-E-R-space) and it takes time to get accustomed to be able to control all five fingers of one hand, but that's what makes the game a real challenge and not just a let's-kill-that-guy-by-poking-his-ribs-with-a-screwdriver kind of game. It's a game, and there should be some challenge, and this game offers even that.It's summer sale and the price is right, the game is totally worth what it costs. Go and buy it. (It also has Steam Trading Cards so you can proudly flaunt your fake medical license badge on Steam lol.)TL;DR: Crack someone's sternum with a hammer for a heart transplant.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												Welcome to Surgeon Simulator 2013, where you get to step into the shoes of our protagonist, a (rather clumsy) surgeon. As the name suggests, you get to be a surgeon in-game and you can perform operations of varying degrees of difficulty. I will give in-depth details below, based on what I have garnered from my playtime:The game is very open-ended. The only objective you have is to perform the surgery without killing off your patient (read: bleeding him to death). There are a variety of tools available and you can generally use most of them to achieve your goal. There is, of course a best possible way to achieve something and a worst possible way but hey, it's just a game.Since there is no actual science involved, the surgeries in themselves are hilarious and it just results in hours and hours of fun; also, I am pretty sure brain transplants aren't possible yet. The absence of any real science gives a humorous edge to the game.Another thing I really enjoyed was the part where I could perform the uber-heart transplant (is that what it's called?) on the Heavy weapons guy (you play as the Medic from TF2). It was extremely hilarious and reminded me of ye olde TF2 trailer, and playing it was like a reward for all the effort it took to put the VHS tape into the damn machine.The controls were really awkward (A-W-E-R-space) and it takes time to get accustomed to be able to control all five fingers of one hand, but that's what makes the game a real challenge and not just a let's-kill-that-guy-by-poking-his-ribs-with-a-screwdriver kind of game. It's a game, and there should be some challenge, and this game offers even that.It's summer sale and the price is right, the game is totally worth what it costs. Go and buy it. (It also has Steam Trading Cards so you can proudly flaunt your fake medical license badge on Steam lol.)TL;DR: Crack someone's sternum with a hammer for a heart transplant.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 25, 2013
												This is one of those games that you show to your friends, and everyone begs you to let them have a go on it. But the thing is, you don't want to let them have a go because you're too busy hammering away at the patients rib-cage to even notice your friends are in the room. When you've only got a little while to spare, you'll find yourself opening up this game. Whilst the storyline is a little outrageous, the amount of fun that you'll have getting used to the controls and getting stuck right into a heart transplant (warning: contains no medical accuracy, whatsover!) far outweights the outrageousness. The developers have given it a bit of a sense of humor too, even the title menu is a game all in it's self! There's secret missions, and hilarious achievements everywhere, waiting to be found. Just for the love of god, don't drop your wristwatch or a scalpel into the patient, it's a bit of a pain to get back out again.Anyway, usually I'm not a massive indie game fan, but this is utter brilliance. I've seen the price drop super low during the sales for this game, and I bought it myself at the lowest price I've seen yet, but I'd happily pay more than what I already have for this game, and that's saying something!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 19, 2013
												Not an actual surgeon simulator - just a silly game about trying to perform surgery using only a selection of appropriate and not-so-appropriate tools manipulated by a ridiculously hard-to-control human arm. It's actually quite fun once you get the hang of it, and the surgical procedures are fully do-able. Just don't expect to do a professional job!The game was originally extremely short but has been expanded to include an outer-space mode for its three basic surgeries and an extra set of operations on a space alien in which the organs have ludicrous names and you have to basically guess your way through the alien's unfamiliar anatomy, which is more fun than it sounds.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												Surgeon Simulator 2013 doesn't feel like an actual game nor does it try to recreate surgery within a game. What it does do is add humour in the way that the controls are merely clunky and unforgiving whilst you nervously attempt to carry out surgery. The game itself is funny for about 5 minutes as the character you are controlling is so clumsy that he knocks over everything in his sight but I don't think Surgeon Simulator 2013 is really a game that is intended to be serious. What it does do exceptionally well is try and attempt to put you in a situation where you are mentally instable, drunk and have no idea what you are doing, yet manage to carry out surgery. I wouldn't say that this a game worthy of its £6.99 pricetag seeing as it really is nothing but silliness and a short moment of laughs. I guess it would give good bragging rights if you're able to complete surgery in the fastest time with the least blood lost or whatever but as a standalone game to pay money for? Nope.

												For medical students seeking a real-life surgeon simulator look no further.  Clinicals will be a breeze after a few hours fine-tuning your skills.  I would say pre-med students could benefit as well if they poccess enough knowledge about surgery and have a sound medical vocabulary.  This isn't some goofy sim catering to those folks who just want to get a good laugh; it's for those of us who are really striving to make a real difference in the world by being the best damn medical professionals possible.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 31, 2014
												I would recommend buying the base game of Surgeon Simulator if you have been thinking about it. It is great fun and actually quite addicting, plus the achievements for this game are simple yet challenging enough to make you want to complete all of them. Or at least it made me want to try and get them all. The soundtrack is so good that I bought it (available on Bandcamp) and the game itself is really well optimised. So by all means buy the base game. However,The new 'Anniversary Edition' content for this game I cannot possibly reccomend. The menus are completely changed to be more touch friendly and less mouse friendly, which is actually quite a big deal when you have to manually push each button with your virtual hand. The 2 new surgeries are pretty finickity and dull compared to the old ones, and for some reason they don't look half as good. Although this could be due to my next point. There is a new extended options menu in the DLC, this gives you all the options you would expect for a standard PC game. But, for some reason the new setting lag the game to crap. On the base game there was low, medium and high graphics settings. On my 3.2 Ghz i7 8GB ram PC I could run the old base game on high without any lag issues or slowing of any sort with no noticable drops in FPS. But with the new DLC the game lags even on the lowest settings, and the highest settings don't look half as good as they used to. This for me is the biggest problem with the DLC, it must have been shipped out in a hurry with little to no optimisation. There's a new corridor mode and lots of new achievements (which you have available even without the DLC, making it impossible to 100% the Steam achievements without buying the DLC) but really this expansion has ruined the base game for me and after playing it for an hour I uninstalled the expansion all together. Unless there is an update pretty soon I'm going to be hoping Austrailia's court case for Steam refunds goes worldwide, and then ask for one myself.Base game 10/10Expansion -10/10 (because it also ruins the base game)

content:
Posted: January 20, 2014
												7/10In a word "GGgggggggggggggggggyyyaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaahhhh!"The learning curve on this one is ridiculously steep, and not for the faint of heart. There is no introductory level, no tutorial, just you trying to figure out how to use the hand of a surgeon to full effect. That's all there is to the gameplay, but it's more than enough to occupy your attention, as you try to eventually grab one of the tools and then attempt to actually use it. Apearance-wise, it reminds me somewhat of Bullfrog's Sim hospital, which I loved. The simplicity of design and difficulty of controls made this one of 2013's more controversial Greenlight releases, Surgeon Simulator is a struggle to get to grips with (ya see what I did there).I personally found the balance between frustrating and compelling to be about right, and maybe one day I'll manage to finish the first stage.

content:
Posted: August 14, 2014
												I reccomend this game. Listen, if you think I'm in no place to be judging it, take this into concideration:I legitimately got an A++ on every mission, and I got a 100% no blood loss brain sugery.I know what I'm talking about.Lots of people complain about the way this game runs, but it runs perfectly for me and I have a terrible pc. I can barely run skyrim on medium graphics. This game runs perfectly if you want to mess with the options a small bit.The game's controls are terrible.BUT THAT'S THE POINT. YOU'RE PLAYING AS A DRUGGED UP SURGEON. YOU'RE NOT MEANT TO BE IN CONTROL OF A SOBER HUMAN, YOU PLAY AS NIGEL BURK, A MAN ADDICTED TO PILLS. Hence why he has drugs on his desk (pills) and why you can inject yourself with the hallucinatory drugs during the operations.If you still feel like I don't know enough about this game, I can tell you that I have all of the achievements :/I definately reccomend this game, it's long, it takes a while to learn, and it's fun. Slamming radios into people's ribcages is fun. Drilling a hole in your patient's head is fun. Making your patient a timelord is fun. Getting every mission A++'d is fun.This game is fun. I reccomend it especially with the new update for the anniversary coming out.

content:
Posted: February 1, 2014
												This game is hilarious! The absolute mayham is funny not because it's trying to be funny, but that it is just IN-YOUR-FACE WTF moments. The first thing to mention is the controls. Genius! Takes a while to get used to, but that's part of the fun! The acheivements have little comments about pop-culture that will make you chuckle, but some of the best things happen in the reception desk. Try and pick up the phone sometime, and you'll get a funny call from one of Nigel's friends. The best part of this game is the surgeries. "Takes someone's lungs, intestines, and ribs to replace a heart. I think the patient will live." The absolute neglect of carefulness with the patient (Bob) is hilarious. But hey, you can lodge a drill into a guy's skull, and that's always fun (I am not a murderous psycopath)! I highly reccomend this game. Best Simulator I've ever played. 9/10

content:
Posted: January 18, 2014
												Surgeon Simulator 2013 is a over-the-top humourous game that has to do with surgery, but it's not too serious when it comes to performing a heart transplant or kidney. It's also fictional because of the brain transplant, I mean c'mon you can't perform a brain transplant in real life, but this game went above and put it in anyways just for the hell of it. I got to thank the community for voting this great, fast-paced, humourous game into steam so I'm really happy I got this game of course.     This game's final score would be 9.4/10 as it's humor, and fast-paced action was good, and I got to admit for about a few months I was addicted to the music and I couldn't stop playing it.
