number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 28, 2013
												You're a disembodied, outstretched forearm with no elbows. Nothing works. You can barely pick up a pencil from a table. What's more, the collision physics either sends things flying or has them slip away, even when you know what to do. That Jurassic Park Trespasser game from years ago already "blessed" us with a similar sort of absurd interface as it asked players to kill dinosaurs, so there's only one remaining course of action: perform transplant surgeries with zero in-game tutorials or instruction provided until after you've already succeeded.This is absolutely not something you want to go to Youtube or GameFAQs for instruction on when you're stuck. That'll just ruin the game for you. For SS2013 is a game about screwing things up royally and not really minding too much that you've done so. In fact, most of the "achievements" are granted based on ridiculous ways to screw things up, not succeed. For although you're presented with all sorts of tools to go about your task, most of them are either useless or actively detrimental. Normally, this would all make for an atrocious experience. But the "Simulator" of the title is a complete and absolute lie. I originally had a paragraph elaborating on this, but the joy is seeing for yourself. Originally made in 48 hours, the "2013" version of this game was made in 48 days. The absurd novelty of it all it seems to be part of a slight swell of indie "perform mundane tasks in goofy fashion" games. There are 8 operations total, but only 4 unique procedures. Naturally, the toughest one of all--the heart transplant--is what they have you do first!I paid $3.39 for this and got about 9 hours playtime out of it. WORTH EVERY CENT.

content:
Posted: January 9, 2014
												A heartwarming story about a man named Nigel Burke who was born with a physical and mental disability that made him unable to speak, write and he only had one hand. He also had trouble controlling his body movements as his brain functioned slowly. One day, he litterally ran into an old friend of his with his car and that old friend was Bob. Bob was his one and only friend at school and took care of Nigel everytime he got bullied. Bob had no idea how Nigel even got a car, as he had no liscense. As soon as Nigel rushed Bob to the hospital, the Doctors said they would not have enough time to save Bob. Nigel, not willing to give up on his old pal, immediately rushed into the surgery room and performed the surgery himself. The surgeons impressed, hired Nigel, and Nigel lived happly ever after, going to his new job everyday to find himself crashing his car into Bob everyday. Injuring a different part of Bob and having to perform surgery on him each day.29/10 - IGNOPTiC Clan Approved#1 Swaggiest game on steam - {LINK REMOVED}

content:
Posted: November 30, 2015
												The Controls... they are BAD!! In a good way. It forces you to get used to them, keep your hands steady, and things that real surgeon would do. And once your used to them and all your tools and puncture points, you're on your way to become the world's greatest surgeon, Maybe even out of this world (spoiler alert)Sometimes, you may just want to feel like sticking your hand into the game when their left kidney jusy wont cooperate getting out. That is not a good feeling. But one just mad enough to make you want to keep trying. It's worth the money. Especially when you just played too much Counter-Strike: Global Offensive and you just need a break, a game to wash of the gold nova misery. That's Surgeon Sim. !

You think those are MOBAs, this is true MOBA!For those of you fighting maniacs, Marvel vs Capcom, Tekken, and Street Fighter, you haven't played a true fighting game if you haven't fought for your patient's life in Surgeon Simulator!What is Hearthstone...where is the heart?? Surgeon Simulator contains a real heart! Plus, it uses more imagination than Minecraft!! For those of you who hates your children playing violent FPS games like COD, buy this game instead, as it will teach your children to help save people instead of brutally murdering their brains out!This game has a better ending than Walking Dead! Because you will experience the Walking Live!!!You like Sims?? Then how about you try surgeon SIM- ulator!! :< Do you know who you are paying that enormous amount of money when you die in GTA?? IT IS NIGEL BURKE you are paying! Wish you can be like Yoda?? Well go in space to perform surgery and you can use the Force!You want to save a princess like Mario? This game should even be remade in XBOX ONE and PS4!I think that STEAM made a mistake of putting only three genres for Surgeon Simulator. Any genre you can think of, it's there! content:
Posted: January 11, 2015
												Recommended if you are patient only. Hillarious but the humor will wear off. Everyone else, skip it. Unless if you are forcing yourself to play these games to some how teach yourself patience. Lol! The most frustrating game! This is the same as OCTODAD game and other similar sim games where you try to do something and the only challenge is either gravity or the fact that the game won't let you get things done because it offers no other skill other than the game itself preventing you to play it. My experience with it was: step 1 do what they want me to do.step 2 I can't so i try something else.step 3 watching the patient die because i couldnt do what i was supposed to do.step 4 killing the patient from doing more damage to it.step 5 pass the challenge or fail and re-try.step 6 the humor fades and you realise there are too many games like these and so many others that are world's better. This is a short entertainment only.It has no challenge and no skill. It is like the devs wanted to make a game and couldn't so it handles terribly and then they slap a sim label on it. There is a lot more to a sim game besides this. Plenty of other sim games out there. Preventing a player from playing & then charging them for it shouldn't be considered a challenge at any point in time.Space engineers is a sand box game for builders but that quickly went out the window since things are moving away from you every time and there is no real setting to remove that function in sand box mode. This is not recommended for impatient people. It reminded me of this game where there is a constant in-game interruption preventing you from playing. Recommended for the patient people only. Worth it's price but just not for me.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2014
												You play the akward left arm of a suspicious 'surgeon' conducting various very, very sensitive operations in very not subtle ways. With pretty much full control of the arm, hand and wrist movements of said underqualified left arm, you must conduct transplants as best as you can without butchering your vict...er patient. The overall akwardness of the controls and style of the game lead to some incredibly amusing situations where you are daintily trying to level out someones brain with a pencil, accidentally drug yourself or decide a hammer is the best way to get rid of that pesky ribcage. Surgeon Simulator is not a serious game by any means and really comes into itself when played with two people locally, strangely not advertised as this is the most fun part of the experience imo. One person controls the fingers and the other controls the arm and wrist. Let the insanity ensue!

A funny but frustrating game!This game is not one to be taken too seriously, as it is basically another version of QWOP or any of those other reaally annoying games. The game has some humour like you can rip body parts out of the patient and he/she/alien will still survive.This is a more polished version than the free one you can find on the internet, and it provides a lot more challenges and characters to operate on such as an alien or the heavy from Team Fortress 2. Also, I think that the operations are actually more beatable in this version.This game is more of a hilarious way to pass the time and if you like goofing around then this is the game for you!

content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												Strangely addictive.  It's got a steep learning curve, but I got used to the controls after about fifteen minutes.  Four hours later, my eyes hurt and my hands were shaking.  I went downstairs and told my wife the good news: The heart transplant was successful.  The bad news?  We smashed his ribcage, and his lungs fell out the back of the ambulance.  And I'm pretty sure my wristwatch is still in the chest cavity.She looked at me funny.Anyway, it won't hold your attention for long, but it's definitely worth picking up on sale if you want to try something different for a day or two.

content:
Posted: December 4, 2014
												*Beep* *Beep* *Beep*The steady rythm of the paiten's heart monitor only added to the tension as I strapped on my digital wrist watch and prepped for my first day in surgery. Doctor Hoffman said I was ready. My wife encouraged me on by promising me a healthy Brinner when I got home. I had a drive to not let this paitent go. Brinner is every man's fantasy.So I picked up my knife. I didn't need any gloves, I knew my hands were clean. Wiping the sweat off my brow I opened my paitent up then suddenly I felt my hand move involuntarily. It was as if I had a sudden case of Parkensons disease. Shaking and trembling I grabbed the hammer. With a thud I hear it slam into the rib cage of my paitent, shattering the ribs to pieces. (#*$(@ I just done screwed up my first surgery. The nurse screaming at the ammount of blood loss the paitent was having. I quickly grabbed the heart and threw it into the garbage. Then taking the transplant heart I dropped it in and then the Nurse told me I had pased. My grade was A.Being the pro surgeon I was I called it a day. I figured the paitent's body would fix the other messes I made. I went home and enjoyed my Brinner.It was a good Brinner.A+ Very relistic simulation.P.S. The paitent did in fact live.

Posted: October 17, 2014
												Personally, I do not enjoy this game. Maybe it's because I'm not good at it or I've just lost interest. But here's my review of it.For one, the graphics are nice and simplistic. The controls themselves are tricky, but that's part of the game. The tasks you must complete are nice because it isn't the exact same thing each time. It places you in different environments and allows you to use a wide range of tools to complete your given task. The music is nice and so is the fact that you can kill your patient. Once again, I don't like this game but I know many people do, and I can see why. It's a good game for people who like difficult challenges and/or like to rage over losing a tool.7/10 Would say more but I don't know what else to say.

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 9, 2014
												I had an interest of this game, since PewDiePie made it so popular by surgering Bob and that creepy alien, so I decided to pick it at Christmas sale for 75% off. Surgeon Simulator is absolutelly amazing surgering simulation, where you have to perform a heart, kidney or brain transplant in surgery room, ambulance (yes, organs tend to fly out of the truck) and in the space. Game itself is beatable in fairly ~5 hours, depends on how well and fast you can control each finger and arm movement. Ofcourse, during the surgery, to increase entertainment, you will be provided with some unusual equipment, like shuriken and tomahawk. Yes, this game has many secret achievements, which took another 5 hours to get, but it was a great fun. I strongly suggest this game to anyone, who loves funny game-play and a lot of blood!My rating: 8.5/10

content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												"They told me I could be anything. I became a alcholic doctor that had five shots of whiskey, half a bottle of vodka, seven beers, a bottle of rum, and drank almost two bottles of scotch."- Wise words from a near dead homeless psychopathic drunk that you play in Surgeon Simulator 2013Let's start this review from this totally silly and insane game, with the difficulty and gameplay.Gameplay: This is hard. It's really flipping hard. My friends told me Fallout 3 was hard, but in comparistion it Fallout is like playing any Call of Duty game on easy mode. I do not recommend this game if you do not like hard games. I dont like this game very much. It's way too hard for a person like me. I shouldn't have to give you a warning! This game is about having to do surgery with one hand and having no one to help you. Remember what I say about the difficulty before buying this game, you little psychopath, you.Soundtrack: Amazing. Just......why wouldn't you like the soundtrack? Please go die in a nuclear fire if you dont like it.  Art style: I love it. Nigel's hand kind-of looks like the medic's hand in TF2. There is actually a TF2 styled level! You're the medic and you replace the heavy's heart, just like in the Meet the Medic trailer. And.....it's harder than I thought.........So...yeah.Why shouldn't I get this game?The only reason I can think of is....again....is that this game's really hard. If you're like me, I enjoy sawing through peoples bones, but the blood goes quick and cutting through the bones and kidneys and hearts and lungs is really hard to cut through with one hand. But if you think you're a good enough doctor to do it with one hand. Go right ahead.Why should I get this game?It's silly, original, and you get to show the middle finger to your soon-to-be victim. In the end, I recommend this game because it's something new! Something funny and silly! Get this game if you have bought the other awesome games of the sale. There may be better and more fun games than this, but this game will keep the glued to the screen for some time.8/10*Gaben voice* Thanks! And have fun!

number of helpful: 10 of 19 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												So I was recommended this game recently and it's been a journey to say the least.First off, understand this: Surgeon Simulator is a mock of a true simulator.  It is mocking other simulators complicated, sometimes frustrating controls, and it excels at that.  It is also is also a mockery of surgery in general, kind of a bummer if you ever played Life and Death from '88.  To be fair, a true surgery simulator wouldn't be well received.  This game has you breaking out ribcages, allows you to throw organs on the floor (after you take them out you don't put them back in, save for the replacement heart/kidney/brain), and has you do so with the most ridiculous tools available. To some, that sounds great.  Not me.  I enjoy true simulators such as MS Flight Sim, Euro Truck, and SimCity.  In those games, I don't really find the controls too challenging, so I don't really get the joke here.  I've heard of QWOP, which is essentially a jogging simulator where you control the thighs/calves separately, and must maintain balance while doing so.  Not really my cup of tea either.  So if you like the idea of frustratingly bad controls, or might find the humor in it, give it a try.  There's a free version out there (as any good sim should have) to make sure you enjoy before you buy.It's not for everyone, but it's for some.  There are definitely some hilarious moments, such as raging on your desk in reception, answering the phone, and making all the (rude) hand gestures at the patient, but after that the bad controls lost their luster on me.Surgeon Sim gets a 2/5.TawokSteam: Apocky+TawokPSN/Xbox: Tawok

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 14, 2013
												Surgeon Simulator 2013 is the dark and gritty tale of Nigel. Nigel is an ex-surgeon who gambles away all of his money on internet poker, and is violentely thrust back into the dark and traumatic world of surgery to pay off his debt. This game features Gore filled and riveting scenes such as Nigel preforming heart surgery, heart surgery in an ambualnce, heart surgery in space, heart surgery on an alien, heart surgery on the Heavy, and much more. If you're tired of all of the crap that the games industry has put out and are in need of a dark, shocking, emotionally powerful, and overall graphically stunning masterpiece that will make you question your own morals, then this game is for you.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 6, 2013
												This game sucks so much it's awesome! Odd but surprisingly true! The controls are so ungodly bad (but innovative) it makes the game unneededly challenging, but that's the whole point of this game, trust me! Picking up a tool isnt as simple as.. well.. just picking it up. You will find Nigel to pick up the tool just however he wishes for (or more specificaly: how the tool just happend to be on the table).Don't dare to think this game to be a respectful (surgeon) simulator, because it's far from it. But this game isn't really bad, it has just been made to be ridiculous! And it works! For me atleast.But the controls are not the only thing that makes this game challenging. The first three operations (which are heart transplant, double kidney transplant and brain transplant) are in the surgeon room, but the next three operations are in a moving ambulance and the next three in space!! You maybe should not pay the whole 10€, (seriously, who would pay so much for a game that is so broken like it is?) Wait for a sale and then, whatever the price, it's worth your laughs! The 10€ price tag isn't there for how awesome this game is, i suppose, it's more likely because this game is so ridiculous. But that alone isn't worth much.But anyway, all in all, it's worth your laughs and you should try it!7.5/10PS. Who the hell does brain transplants anyway? O_O - Nigel does!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2013
												This game is INCREDIBLY difficult, but that's actually the point. You have very basic control of your single hand, and can curl each finger individually, rotate the wrist, and generally move the whole arm around the screen in your pursuit of a variety of surgical feats. The difficulty in controlling the numb-seeming appendage is part of the appeal, and the actual hilarity of the game. Failure is not really a failure, as you can retry any surgery as many times as you want, and you even get rated on how quickly you can kill your patient. Of course, there's entertainment in succeeding in the surgery as well, including a rating, and the potential to unlock the next surgery. This game boasts several hidden surgeries, including with characters from TF2 (heavy and medic). It's delightyfully creative, a bit bloody, and generally quite fun.I would advise caution if you are squeamish, dislike the sight of blood, or find the thought of wrapping a patient's intestine around his neck (purely by accident) to be faintworthy.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2016
												I love Surgeon Sim. I still play sometimes. I like playing in Skype calls and I'll screen share, make my friends tell me what to do while they oversee the operation. The game's clunky as **** but that's kind of the point. It runs great, and does what it tries to do well. There are a few levels I absolutely hate and feel the game would be much better without them. I like the  space  level but it's really hard tog rab things. I'm pretty good and it's still really hard. In more of a clunky way than a well designed diffuclty way. But like I said, that's kind of what the game's built around. Being beautifuly clunky.

content:
Posted: August 14, 2014
												Surgeon Simulator 2013 is the best medical simulator released in 2006.  When it was released it was lauded for its realism and general helpfulness in training baby surgeons.  It has since been given several awards and is still used to train med school students and provides the best surgical training in a virtual environment.  I highly recommend it.  97 out of 100.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												Easily recommended. Very fun, and very frusting. At some points you might question yourself why you bought this game, and why you even live. You will at almost every point in a surgery want a refund, but a voice in your head will keep calling you saying, "Jonathan, come back. I just want you to play me for the rest of your life." Anyways, hope your experience isn't as terrifying as mine. If you're looking for an easy game, this isn't it. The iPhone/iPad version is a lot easier though. Be prepared.

												Have you ever spooned in bed with someone? You know how you never have a place for your non-spooning arm so you tuck it under your head, under your body or maybe just shove it behind you? That's Surgeon Simulation 2013.  And it's wonderful.

content:
Posted: December 14, 2014
												This is hands down one of the best games I own in my Steam Library. It's highly entertaining and requires a great amount of skill, patience, persistence, and dedication. The soundtrack is amazing 80s-esque and the graphics aren't bad. There are a good amount of missions and plenty to keep you busy for a long time. I currently have 68% of the achievements but I don't think I'll get more than that. The timed achievements are ludicrously difficult. At times this game can be frustrating beyond belief, and there are glitches from time to time (hammer flying spontaneously from my hand, brain flailing/glitching once you pull it out during transplant, etc.). I happened to get this game on the cheap in a bundle and didn't really expect much from it. However, after all of the time I've put into it (20+ hours), I can easily say that it's worth every penny at the full price. I also bought the DLC for the additional operations since I enjoyed it so much. One thing that does bother me about this game is that the save game is stored in the registry (not steam cloud sync). If you move steam to another computer you will have to transfer the registry file to the new computer to get your progress back. There are resources on how to do this, just look around online if you have this issue like I did. Overall I really enjoyed this game, I just wish I was good enough to get 100% completion on the achievements. Maybe one day, a man can dream!

content:
Posted: December 21, 2013
												Over the top.One of the many ways you can describe a game that tells you to give a man a brain transplant and then puts a hatchet, a power drill, a hand-operated buzz-saw and a high-powered laser within reach.In a world where you get an achievement for completing the transplants while both drugged and electrocuted, why would it even matter that your heart transplant patient was left with just a heart where there once laid a set of lungs, a stomach and a liver under a ribcage?The controls, while touch-and-go at times (though this was likely intended by the developers, else why would A, W, E, R, Space and the mouse be used to control a single arm and hand) make it a challenge yet to be seen in other games, albeit accompanied by many a time spent ranting and raving at the screen because you wanted to pick up the green syringe, not stab yourself with the blue one and impale a claw hammer in your patient.The ridiculousness of the game is only taken further by the challenge of performing the operations in an ambulance (complete with corners sending your equipment flying around and the doors opening before you can pick up the replacement heart), and then even further to space, meaning that you need to keep going back to make sure your scalpels are where you left them and not drifting off where you can't reach, and you need to make sure that the container for the organ is shut tightly, else it be lost to the back of the room. After that, you can even go so far as to operate on an alien, after accidentally stumbling across the jettison codes for the makeshift zero-g theatre and being abducted from the vacuum of space.All in all, it's a great way to pass the time. The game is specifically structured so that even killing your patient is difficult short of taking a hatchet to their skull.

content:
Posted: April 26, 2013
												Cut, hack, smash, save, murder... Those are the things one can do in the comedic, ragdoll physics based game Surgeon Simulator 2013. Surgeon Simulator is a very addicting and fun game. It's pretty short yet I still find entertainment in doing the same surgeries repeatedly as there are a lot of tools and objects to try out. Speaking of objects Surgeon Simulator offers a wide variety of things to pick up and use on the patient or whatever is desired, ranging from the common medical scalpel to the unorthodox medieval battle axe. That's what makes Surgeon Simulator stand out. The absurd objects and physics. Over all Surgeon Simulator 2013 is a fine independent game with a lot of comic value making it a ton of fun.

number of helpful: 41 of 82 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												    Imagine performing surgery within a claw-crane toy vending machine.  The surgeon's single hand is, by design, one of the clumsiest manifestations of inter-activity ever published.  Of course this would be the very point and what makes it so much fun! The difficulty in getting anywhere because of this intentional disconnect with user input can, however, be frustrating at times.  I personally require a mouse pad the size of Central Park in order to move the arm around (even on the highest sensitivity).  It's definitely presented as a joke game, not an achievement or skill game, although those things are very much required to get anywhere.  There is no advice or direction in how to approach a given surgery, lots of bloody fun in the trial and error.  Too difficult to grasp objects in general, it can take an eon to get the scalpel in your hand at the right angle for incision.  Certainly not realisitic, and the title "simulator" here must be taken with a grain of salt.  Or a salt mine even.         On the positive, I totally knew what I was getting into and got a deal on the game anyway, so it's no travesty that's happened here.  The game really is pretty funny, and that seems to be it's greatest achievement.  I had  dreams of a more balanced mix of sim and parody...but got mostly the latter.           If  the hand were SLIGHTLY more dexterous, I would've enjoyed it more.  I'm sure it must be rewarding for true mouse-keteers that eventually hone their precision with the movements... that seems the only way to advance passed the first surgery even.  When the difficulty in progressing becomes more frustrating than fun, a game generally loses me.

content:
Posted: October 5, 2014
												Surgeon Simulator is a pretty epic title which will make your friends laugh, yourself rage, and the completionist in you boil with anticipation. While it is a pretty small scale affair, there is plenty of challange to be found in cutting people up and trying not to kill them. The basic concept is this, you have 3 different kinds of basic surgery (5 with the DLC) and have to perform them in the best possible way in a series of different locales (OR, [DLC: Corridor], Ambulance and Space)- with each completed task you  unlock both the next surgery and normally something snazzy for your desk. You can be given new things to play with, new floppy disk tutorials or hints towards secret surgeries. The secret surgeries add a total of 7 new challenges, and while at first they seem impossible it is very possible to struggle through them. As it stands Surgeon Simulator 2013: Anniversary Edition is much improved on its original offerings and will provide you with lots of enjoyment and rage. I do hope they continue to update this title and release new content but as it stands I do feel it is worth your time and money.

content:
Posted: August 4, 2013
												When a certain hapless Bob comes in with another medical problem, Nigel, an enthusiastic surgeon puts matters into his own hands. Or should that be "hand"? Unfortunately, Nigel has only one and even that one is hard to handle. But that shouldn't get in the way when there is surgery to be done, especially when it's transplants of the heart, kidneys and brain.With a tonne (metric) of achievements to keep the intensity on, and Team Fortress 2 characters joining the game for a special operation, Surgeon Simulator 2013 promises absolute hilarity, and that's just the main menu! Ribs grow back!

content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												    Imagine performing surgery within a claw-crane toy vending machine.  The surgeon's single hand is, by design, one of the clumsiest manifestations of inter-activity ever published.  Of course this would be the very point and what makes it so much fun! The difficulty in getting anywhere because of this intentional disconnect with user input can, however, be frustrating at times.  I personally require a mouse pad the size of Central Park in order to move the arm around (even on the highest sensitivity).  It's definitely presented as a joke game, not an achievement or skill game, although those things are very much required to get anywhere.  There is no advice or direction in how to approach a given surgery, lots of bloody fun in the trial and error.  Too difficult to grasp objects in general, it can take an eon to get the scalpel in your hand at the right angle for incision.  Certainly not realisitic, and the title "simulator" here must be taken with a grain of salt.  Or a salt mine even.         On the positive, I totally knew what I was getting into and got a deal on the game anyway, so it's no travesty that's happened here.  The game really is pretty funny, and that seems to be it's greatest achievement.  I had  dreams of a more balanced mix of sim and parody...but got mostly the latter.           If  the hand were SLIGHTLY more dexterous, I would've enjoyed it more.  I'm sure it must be rewarding for true mouse-keteers that eventually hone their precision with the movements... that seems the only way to advance passed the first surgery even.  When the difficulty in progressing becomes more frustrating than fun, a game generally loses me.

content:
Posted: March 20, 2015
												I was expecting a top-of-the-line learning tool for medical studies, but am bitterly disappointed that this game is nothing at all like real surgery.  I am shocked that they would even dare to call it a "simulator".  The representation of the human body and its organs is laughable at best, the surgical processes are simplified to crude hammering, slicing, dicing and flinging, and my "hands" act as if they're almost paralyzed, they're so cumbersome.  Jack the Ripper himself would scoff at this brutal mess of a "game".What could have been a helpful tool for the medical profession, and indeed for the betterment of humanity and the human condition, is reduced to outright nonsense.  Look elsewhere if you are seeking a valuable learning experience.  However, if utter mayhem involving helplesshuman bodies, all manner of blunt/sharp/shiny/pokey/breaky objects (medical and otherwise), and sheer unmitigated madness is your idea of a "fun" time, then perhaps this offering is for you, you sad and demented person.I know it's right up my street.9/10

content:
Posted: May 30, 2013
												Like all good jokes, Surgeon Simulator 2013 knows when to stop. You could easily get through most of the content in an hour or two – something that the game's price prepares you for. The game is broken into three operations; heart transplant, kidney transplant and brain surgery. Once done, you'll get to do them all over again but in the back of an ambulance, where speed bumps and sharp turns constantly hurl your equipment around. Once your patient, Bob, has been "patched up" for the sixth time, you've seen most of the game. Although you do have the option to replay old stages to improve your previous time and rankings.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												Imagine, if you will, attempting to perform surgery with a neuromuscular disorder. That's Surgeon Simulator 2013 in a nutshell,You control the surgeon's arm. Yes, you're a one-armed surgeon apparently. Each finger is controlled by a corresponding key while the arm and hand itself is guided by the mouse. So far so good, right? Think again.Try pressing and holding all five keys, and if you're lucky, three of the fingers will close. Sometimes you can get all the fingers to cooperate, but often you end up trying to interact with little success. Assuming you can get the fingers, hand, and arm to function properly, you still have to deal with the awkward physics (drop a hammer and watch it bounce about like a basketball, often ending up on the floor where you can no longer retrieve it) and terribly clumsy object detection. Try to grab a scalpel, for instance, and you'll probably end up gripping it by the blade or be forced to contort your arm in various positions to simply make a small cut.The actual surgery itself pitiful in its implementation, You're barely given any equipment, and what little you have is mixed among ridiculous items. When you use your tools, the patient begins bleeding profusely and there's no way to cauterize wounds or inject atropine to deal with a dangerously low heart rate.All in all, SS2013 tries to be humorous and even make fun of itself, but the gimmick wears thin about 5 minutes into your first operation (if it hasn't already done so at the reception desk). You end up spending more time fighting with the controls to do anything rather than playing the actual game, and the task of surgery is really just an excuse to see how many horrible ways someone can be murdered on the operating table.Bottom Line: If you want a game that's essentially a one-trick pony and revolves around torture-disguised-as-surgery, I'd recommend buying Surgeon Simulator 2013 right away. On the other hand, if you want something that at least resembles modern medicine and surgical techniques -- or just doesn't require you to wrestle with the controls every step of the way -- you should do yourself a favor and skip this title entirely. Instead, try an old game (published in 1988) called "Life and Death."

number of helpful: 45 of 91 people (49%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 11, 2014
												Surgeon Simulator 2013 almost falls into the category of "so bad it's good." You play as a disembodied arm and are tasked to cut some bones, pull out some organs, and plop a replacement organ back in. It suffices to say that the word "simulator" in the title is meant to be tongue-in-cheek. There are three stages: a heart transplant, a kidney transplat, and a brain transplant (though, really, shouldn't it be called a "body" transplant?). After completing these stages, you repeat them in an ambulance which ups the difficulty. After you complete these in an ambulance, you repeat them again in space, which ups the difficulty a bit more. Late in the game there are a few bonus surgeries you can do on an alien, but I didn't have the patience to get this far.The main challenge of the game is mastering the awful controls, and there isn't much more to the gameplay besides that. Sure, there are some easter eggs to find, and the over-the-top ridiculousness of game keeps it from being too boring. But, still, I can't imagine most people bothering to play this for more than a few hours tops. So if can you get this game inexpensively, it is good for a cheap laugh. Other than that, it's not really worth playing.My rating: 2/5

number of helpful: 28 of 57 people (49%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2013
												People will have absolutely differing opinions on Surgeon Simulator. On one hand, it is a very quirky and somewhat cathartic game: where else are you actually *encouraged* to permanently remove a person's lungs in order to do a heart transplant --- which is a simple matter of dropping that squishy-looking red blob into the open chest of a heavily anesthesized person.On the other hand, the controls are very difficult to get used to. They are really awkward, and you may find yourself cursing because you dropped the bone saw, so you would need to improvise by using, say, a hammer to break off ribs. This difficulty is the inherent appealing factor of the game, though, and there are many people who love it. I liked playing the game but only for a very short period of time.You will like this game if you liked playing that flash game named QWOP, where the horrible controls constitute the main game mechanic. In my opinion though, I would not recommend buying this game unless you are already absolutely certain you will enjoy this. I only had a minimal level of enjoyment because the novelty factor ran out for me fairly quickly, and soon became frustrated. I actually thought I would enjoy it a lot, because gameplay videos looked very fun, but fiddling around with the "simple" controls became a most arduous task, and ain't nobody got time for that!

Supposedly there are a lot of surgeries to do but all of them are locked. Great.The only way I would enjoy this game would be to have some friends around me so that we can laugh together at how bad I am at the game. But playing the game by myself makes me want to smash my head in the keyboard. If there is one thing I dont like in games it is to laugh at myself for beeing bad at them. There is no enjoyment there.Dont buy this game. Its fun to look at other people fail at it. Its not fun to fail yourself.

number of helpful: 5 of 11 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 8, 2014
												Surgeon Simulator 2013 is, essentially, a joke. It's a funny joke when played on somebody else, but somehow loses much of the humor when it happens to you.The root of the joke is that this is a surgery game with difficult controls. Which could be kind of funny, on its own. But there's so much else piled on top of that, that it makes the game less amusingly frustrating, and more the regular kind of frustrating. The physics are buggy, for one. Your hand gets stuck in EVERYTHING, and sometimes items go flying with little provocation. Sometimes things just fall out of your hand, even though you had a strong grip on them. 2-1 odds it damages the patient and/or falls on the floor. Nothing is really explained at the start, which is all part of the joke. But the game could at least tell you that the green shot stops bleeding, because your average player is going to have a VERY rough go of it without that knowledge.One of the biggest issues for me was figuring out where to cut things. You can't just cut something wherever. You have to cut at a very precise location or you're just wasting the patient's valuable blood. Even knowing where to cut doesn't always help. I know where to cut the left side of the large intestine, but I always wind up scraping my blades all over the thing before it finally gives way. The bigger-picture problem here is that the game is just finicky. Putting a replacement organ where it belongs doesn't always ensure the end of the level. Oftentimes - especially with the kidneys - you can find yourself knocking the organ(s) all around, just trying to get it/them to register as properly in place.There are only three main surgeries in the game. These are the heart transplant, a double kidney transplant, and a brain transplant which is always unlocked last even though it's honestly the easiest of the three. When you complete one, you unlock the next one, and when you complete all three, you unlock the next location. Initially, you only have to perform the operations in an OR. Then you must repeat them in a speeding ambulance, which is even more difficult than that sounds. After that, you must do them a third time in outer space with no gravity. All of these extra locations are just ways to cover up the lack of totally unique operations and draw more laughs out of the original joke, which ran out of laughs the moment you failed your first ambulance mission.And that's sort of my point. It's not that funny to PLAY Surgeon Simulator. It's vastly more fun to watch somebody else play Surgeon Simulator, and let them rage so you don't have to.There are two bonus surgeries which were added on later. One follows the "Meet the Medic" video from the Team Fortress 2 universe, and is available from the start. You play the Medic, and you must operate on the Heavy. It is essentially a more complex and difficult version of the basic heart transplant, with a TF2 theme permeating it. The other is actually an intriguing and completely unique surgery, but is only unlocked after you have already completed the three main surgeries in all three locations, so I won't be playing that one as I just don't have the patience to reach it.Surgeon Simulator contains a load of amusing easter eggs and has a good sense of humor about itself. Aesthetically, it is actually quite nice. Everything looks great and sounds great. When you're on a roll, everything even feels great. Shimmying a lung or brain out of a patient is a pleasing experience. It's just not pleasing enough to warrant shelling out the cash for the few operations available and all of the frustration you're sure to endure.Surgeon Simulator is an interesting game. It's certainly different. It can even, on rare occasions, be genuinely fun. I don't want to call it terrible, because it's not. But I feel like the joke is lost on the player. Maybe if it had cooperative play so that two players could watch each other bumble and laugh mutually together at each other's misfortune, it would be more fun to experience firsthand. But it doesn't, and so I can't recommend spending your own money on it. But I can absolutely recommend watching somebody else play it on YouTube.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2013
												A fun demo, but not much of a game.Surgeon Simulator is fun to play for ten minutes. It's silly, it's funny, and it's good to watch. But this is unfinished as a game. There are barely any instructions, no tutorial, and nothing to even indicate the requirements for completing a goal. Glitches and bad design decisions make it difficult and unclear how to proceed, and finnicky goal conditions mean you can do everything required but still fail for no reason. Okay, I'm supposed to do a heart transplant - I've put the new heart in, why aren't I winning? Do I need to do something else? Etcetera.By all means pick it up for a few bucks on a sale, but don't buy at full price expecting a complete game.

content:
Posted: March 2, 2014
												Surgeon Simulator 2013 is an oddball. Hilarity will undoubtedly ensue as you fumble around with the intentionally awkward controls, making the game great to play with a few friends standing behind you. Once you get the handle behind it, though, it becomes clear pretty quickly that the game doesn't have much substance beyond that initial laugh factor. The game's actual content is very limited, pretty much only including three procedures, which you can do in a few different environments (table, ambulance, space) to mix up the physics slightly. Even then, each of the three procedures is just one form or another of "smash some bones, take out organ, put new organ in".Surgeon Simulator 2013 isn't necessarily a bad game (even if it is going for the "so-bad-it's-awesome" aesthetic with the terrible controls), but it certainly is a limited one. It's worth grabbing on sale for a few quick laughs. Otherwise, the game really just offers too little to be worthwhile.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2016
												Okay as a timewaster. Got it cheap, and even I am starting to regret this purchase. The collision is absolutely terrible in this game. Stuff clips through your hands, you can clip the lungs straight through the ribcage because it is so terrible. I have accidentally instant-killed a patient  because a tool clipped through the skull and got stuck inside the brain instead of breaking the exterior in the brain transplant operation. This severely lessens the fun, as you have little control on what mistakes you make. The force required to break bones also seems terribly inconsistent. Bonus points subtracted for pulling a petty publicity stunt with this trump stuff. Lelelele edgy political satire. It has obviously crossed a line. This isn't just run of the mill parody... this is just straight up harassment. This game is a neat idea, but it works extremely badly. I can not reccomend this.

content:
Posted: October 27, 2014
												This game is escapism turned up to 11. Use two hands IRL and half your keyboard space, plus your mouse, just to control one hand that doesn't even have a full motion range. Sound ridiculous? It is. Oh so hilariously ridiculous...This is a game for those with a very broad sense of humour, or a well-hidden sadistic streak. When you tear out Bob's lung with a hammer, you have to either laugh, vomit or smile inwardly with sadistic glee. If you chose option one or three, then Surgeon Simulator is well worth the pricetag. If you chose option 2.... then don't watch the trailers.The gameplay is really really hard to describe adequately; but it's like the drinking game version of the boardgame "Operation". Basically, you're taking bits out of Bob (all three patients are apparently named Bob), and then you put a couple of bits back in. All on two time limits - an actual clock, and the "hard limit" of how much blood Bob can phyiscally lose before he/it dies. And Bob will die a lot. Sometimes you'll even get an achievement for killing him. But there are a lot of "oh great the drill is stuck in him, I'd better get the hammer to pull it out... great, now the hammer is stuck too, hand me the circular saw". Eventually you get an understanding of how each tool works and how each body part works; and after a messy time learning all these things you can start performing surgical feats. This game requires a mix of thought, motor skills, practice and patience. The patients, fortunately, are provided - make no mistake, if you tried performing surgeries in this manner IRL you *would* be going away for a long time. In fact, the thing you can leave at the door is realism - a working knowledge of anatomy may be helpful; but I'm thinking more of the kind of knowledge a butcher has than that of a medical professional. If you are a medical professional, leave all that Hippocratic Oath and "duty of care" stuff behind in Surgeon Simulator; at least to begin with. One day it will come in useful as you make precision moves to complete the surgery, but in the early days it's just a case of beating and stabbing the internal organs around until they fall out.I do reccomend this game as a casual, light-hearted bit of entertainment. Some people may like to take it further and develop the skills to be a "pro surgeon", but a lot more players will just enjoy stabbing poor Bob with a drill. And that's an entirely valid way to play Surgeon Simulator; you can get all your money's worth and more out of that kind of slapstick "hmm I wonder what happens when I..." messing around.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 13, 2016
												My only big complaint is that IMO, A&E Edition ruins the game's pacing with the extreme amount of levels it adds. Tooth surgery and eye surgery means that there's too much work to do in order to get to additional levels.However, overall this game's pretty good and probably the best the ironic simulator genre has ever pushed out. People who tell you the controls suck haven't spent enough time with the game. These controls are very much masterable and once you get used to them you can perform all kinds of stuff. It's like saying Toribash has bad controls; it doesn't, it just has unusual controls with a high learning curve. Get past that learning curve and you can do ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ ninja flips and advanced wrestling moves.If you're desperately looking at a "simulator" game that will actually keep you entertained for more than five minutes, Surgeon Sim is definitely for you. Unlike a legion of other games in its genre, your actions have consequences on your environment, it doesn't solely rely on the "haha funny physics and dumb controls" joke to carry the humour, and above all else Surgeon Sim has an actual game buried under the madness.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 13, 2016
												My only big complaint is that IMO, A&E Edition ruins the game's pacing with the extreme amount of levels it adds. Tooth surgery and eye surgery means that there's too much work to do in order to get to additional levels.However, overall this game's pretty good and probably the best the ironic simulator genre has ever pushed out. People who tell you the controls suck haven't spent enough time with the game. These controls are very much masterable and once you get used to them you can perform all kinds of stuff. It's like saying Toribash has bad controls; it doesn't, it just has unusual controls with a high learning curve. Get past that learning curve and you can do ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ ninja flips and advanced wrestling moves.If you're desperately looking at a "simulator" game that will actually keep you entertained for more than five minutes, Surgeon Sim is definitely for you. Unlike a legion of other games in its genre, your actions have consequences on your environment, it doesn't solely rely on the "haha funny physics and dumb controls" joke to carry the humour, and above all else Surgeon Sim has an actual game buried under the madness.

content:
Posted: January 21, 2014
												I could not want to play this game less.After getting use to the loose (read: gimmicky) controls, you enter into you first surgery, a heart transplant. Step 1: crack open the rib cage as destructively as possible while also not causing massive internal hemoraging. While not causing your patient to bleed out is simple enough, cracking a rib cage with a hammer (or the less preferred bonesaw or dremmel) by controlling a flimsy wrist with the x and y axis on the mouse is frusturating and, worse, boring, By my fifth try, I made it to the heart with my patient losing blood only at 3ml/s, but I felt nothing. No risk, no fun, and no pride in managing to become familiar with bad controls that were intentionally created to be bad.It's like Demon Souls...if it were programmed by the old Titus team that made Superman 64.Wait until it's on sale for $1 USD and then make sure you don't need that dollar for a pack of chips from a vending machine.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2014
												This is brilliant! You take the role as a.. Let's say, not-so-well skilled doctor. By that i mean, you'll be put into a surgery where you have to do, let's say a heart transplant. The controls are a, w, e, r, space and mouse. Just like a real hand. Sounds easy? No.. It's not.. That's the thing about this game. It's really difficult to control the hand, and that makes it indeed funny.I totally recommend this game! The only cons would be, that it lacks different types of scenarios. (There's heart transplant, kidney transplant and brain transplant with a few different modes). And you really have to be careful about blood-loss, but that's the fun part too.As i said.. I recommend it, and you should already be buying it right now!

content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
												Unfortunately I went into this with something totally different in mind.  I can definitely see the appeal for anyone who likes to kill time (no pun intended) doing infuriatingly difficult -- though somewhat entertaining -- tasks.  Was I expecting an *actual* surgical simulation? No, not really; and to be honest the sound and blood effects are pretty entertaining on their own.  I guess ultimately my disappointment arises from the fact that the sole purpose of the game really seems to be simply the fact that the surgeon's hand is incredibly imprecise and difficult to control.  Yes, I can see to some degree the comedic value of accidentally knocking a jar into the patient's chest cavity or stabbing them in the heart when you meant to cut their esophagus, but at some point I had to ask myself, "Am I playing this because I like fighting the game's insistence on not doing what I'm trying to control the hand to do, or because I like figuring out how best to perform the surgery and manage blood loss?" I will tell you that the game overwhelmingly shifts toward the former, and I realized that the vast majority of the time wasn't spent figuring out how to do the surgery and keep the patient alive, but simply and almost solely trying to control the surgeon himself.  I got about halfway through before I decided I was tired of fighting the game itself rather than actually playing it.  I guess I don't understand why the devs decided to put all the effort into developing decent graphics, sound effects, music, interface, etc., then phone it in on the controls.If the point is the lack and difficulty of control, then I guess that wasn't something I understood going into it.  So if a game based on fighting with the controls to manipulate an extremely difficult to maniuplate broken robotic quasi surgeon hand, then this game is for you.  If that sounds like it would be a bit frustrating and unfulfilling, you'll want to pass on this game.  I can assure you, the comedic value quickly gets replaced with frustration, annoyance, and regret at having spent the money.6/10

												If you can figure out how to even pick anything up, you have more patience than me. content:
Posted: July 20, 2016
Simply my favorite game since its release!Even after so many years this game still makes me laugh and still brings me a challenge, I always end up playing it again from time to time.It's a funny game, its control difficulties are what makes this game interesting, always being a challenge no matter what.Cartoony graphics to avoid players grossing out while playing, it's simply one of the funniest and most well-made simulators you can find out there.It features:Rage-induncing controls!Many surgery types and levels!Lots of achievements and challenges!Secrets and even ARGs! (more than you would expect)Some actual story/backstory.Gore and Blood (?)Puns, lots of puns.Lots of DLC to keep the game fresh!Someone that just won't stop calling you.Hand-signs support! (not really)Unconscious Trump!Overall: 10/10I would recommend this game to everyone that likes medicine, it clearly isn't a game to accurately simulate a surgery, but it's always worth to visit it sometimes to have a little break out of those stressful jobs involving the art of healing.

content:
Posted: January 28, 2014
												Were this a "calm player-objective driven sandbox" game where you could be fooling around for the most part, I could recommend this "game" to be purchased.However, what we have in hands is actually something that tries to be as "arcade" (read: pick-it-up-and-play-for-the-high score) as possible; and for the most part there is also only single solution, because of reason called "developers dictated so"...Controls aside, which have been already bashed enough already by others, there are some far more "bugger" issues with this title.It all mainly comes down to both the limitation where hand/player can go around and the level layouts:Were one to drop the needed "ingredient" or tool into floor, there is no way to retrieve these aside restarting the stage / "murdering" the patient. Same thing happens when you accidentally push items far too away from your reach when "magnet"-fingers of the player-hand fails to "activate".Then there are simply the item-layout causing huge problems when trying to achieve the main goal; either player-hand cannot be lowered enough due wrist boking into something and halting the decent. Or otherwise there are solid non-movable object preventing the operations itself.The much advertised "Meet the Medic"-stage is guilty of all the unplayability faults mentioned (and many other faults): Good luck All in all, I certainly don't recommending to buy this game (at least alone).But otherwise if for some reason one gets this game to their collection, I for one certainly hope the player is going to face less of the bugs and such (Use bonesaw on ribcage -> lungs phase through <- ribcage still being intact, to name latest bugs I encountered alongside scalpel-immune innards).On a random side-note, I've yet to still see or hear any other surgeon-sections or whole games that actually are not only more or less realistic, but fun to do than "Life & Death"-series (flawed, and certainly far too ahead its time) and that one "mini-game" in "Chaos Break" (which for goodness sake was sort of like more-actiony "Resident Evil", but with non-Earth-invading-cretures (and first introduction to sudokus to me (*I was doing sudokus way before they were cool*)).I can always keep wishing and forget that "Trauma Center"-series was a thing (aside music of course, but that's the "unfortunate" thing with various not-so-good-things; music alone for the most part is far better than the product it was shipped with)...

content:
Posted: November 10, 2013
												Surgeon Simulator is definitely an "experience". Most will likely find this game rather shallow and pointless, but as-it-is can be quite fun. I personally came into very skeptical but once booted I realized time had flown by and I was hooked messing around in someones body as chunks, bones, and tools went flying aroudn the roomMy biggest frustration didn't reside with the completely intentionally absurd controls, but with the total lack of instruction of what to do next to perform a "surgery". Even passing the first surgery was a struggle only because it wasn't clear what was needed to be done. Maybe this was intentional, but on top of the wacky control system, this added an unneccesarry challenge I believe.This will definetly not be a game for everyone, but if you have spare time and want to try something way out of left field, it can be worth a go for a bit. Don't expect it to be a long term satisfying game though.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
												I don't...I can't...*sobs uncontrollably*So many things clipping into other things. Of course, this game is a novelty - Yes, I've barely played it.The ratio of positive to negative reviews is such that I decided to make mine negative (but NOT simply because of that ratio); this is a novel game, I applaud the idea behind it. No doubt, those who check out Surgeon Simulator would understand the premise (though they can hardly appreciate it until they play it... I certainly wasn't prepared, even after having watched a few videos of gameplay) - for those who don't: You control a (")surgeon's(") arm - You can raise, lower and rotate the limb and control each digit individually - You are meant to manipulate objects in the most ham-handed of ways to perform the most delicate of procedures - Hilarity/Frustration/Joy/Rage-Induced-Nausea ensues. If it wasn't for the fact that EVERYTHING is derpy, and not just the controls, I would have recorded this as a Thumbs Up. Just in the half hour I played, though, I kept finding my surgical tools getting stuck in-between and behind ribs that I had yet to (be able to) break (hadn’t even lowered the arm manually). That knife was unavailable until I was able to articulate another tool appropriately to free that first tool… and then the damn knife flew away upon clashing with the hammer (really, that much momentum?). The height of the arm is too finicky, as is the angle at which you hold your wrist. It could go either way: A surgeon would keep their appendage steady - This game is intentionally hard to control. The game could have cut us SOME slack - Where's the fun/challenge in that? Such pleasure still escapes me... understand, though, that entertainment is constant. During my first attempt at the heart-transplant, all of my tools somehow flew off the table (IS THERE NO WAY TO TURN OFF THE DREMEL?!), so I simply beat my patient to death with the clock, to try again... to fail thrice more.I (want to) like this game(‘s idea). I will continue to play it - in short spurts, as that is the extent of my patience with it. Provided I can eventually reckon the mechanics/necessary (")exploits("), I might change the Negative to Positive and add a Zen statement or two to urge others to stick with it. As it is, I wouldn't feel right Recommending it, because of just HOW extremely, er, unintuitive your interactions within the OR are - how SPASMODIC the integrity of the objects within the environment is.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
												Unfortunately I went into this with something totally different in mind.  I can definitely see the appeal for anyone who likes to kill time (no pun intended) doing infuriatingly difficult -- though somewhat entertaining -- tasks.  Was I expecting an *actual* surgical simulation? No, not really; and to be honest the sound and blood effects are pretty entertaining on their own.  I guess ultimately my disappointment arises from the fact that the sole purpose of the game really seems to be simply the fact that the surgeon's hand is incredibly imprecise and difficult to control.  Yes, I can see to some degree the comedic value of accidentally knocking a jar into the patient's chest cavity or stabbing them in the heart when you meant to cut their esophagus, but at some point I had to ask myself, "Am I playing this because I like fighting the game's insistence on not doing what I'm trying to control the hand to do, or because I like figuring out how best to perform the surgery and manage blood loss?" I will tell you that the game overwhelmingly shifts toward the former, and I realized that the vast majority of the time wasn't spent figuring out how to do the surgery and keep the patient alive, but simply and almost solely trying to control the surgeon himself.  I got about halfway through before I decided I was tired of fighting the game itself rather than actually playing it.  I guess I don't understand why the devs decided to put all the effort into developing decent graphics, sound effects, music, interface, etc., then phone it in on the controls.If the point is the lack and difficulty of control, then I guess that wasn't something I understood going into it.  So if a game based on fighting with the controls to manipulate an extremely difficult to maniuplate broken robotic quasi surgeon hand, then this game is for you.  If that sounds like it would be a bit frustrating and unfulfilling, you'll want to pass on this game.  I can assure you, the comedic value quickly gets replaced with frustration, annoyance, and regret at having spent the money.6/10

												I never write lenghty reviews for any game, but I feel like I need to write this in case I can spare at least one person from this horrible piece of software the developpers call a game. Seriously, Do not buy it.Like others have pointed out before me, this game is just a gimmick- You buy it, say "haha I'm performing surgery", and then you probably move on. You wont get your money's worth if you intend to just♥♥♥♥♥♥around like this and you're probably better off watching videos or something. If, on the other hand, you're the type of person who will try to get all achievements and unlockables like myself, the only thing you will get from this game is frustration and a lot of headache; This game controls horribly and if you play for more than an hour you will realize that the success of every operation will likely be the result of random luck or some unhealthy amount of time trying to acquire muscle memory.I don't mind putting in a lot of work in order to beat hard games but this isn't NES megaman difficulty or anything, this is just a studio trying to pass off a bad game with a bad physics engine as a challenge. It's the biggest offense of all in my opinion, because the developpers have the audacity to claim in their FAQ that this game is hard because they wanted people to feel "rewarded" for being able to put up with something they didn't even have to program. This game is just you struggling with some very bad physics for hours on end.It says a lot when the most famous works by Bossa studios is this joke of a game and a haha2funnylol game about bread. It's as unoriginal as it seems and you're better off steering clear of this abomination. And I don't understand the people who will try to defend it because there is no reason to play doctor's advocate here, it's just a bad game. Believe me. I'm not writing this for myself or for the developpers (since I'm sure they made mad $$$ from this already), but for YOU who hasn't bought this game yet and can still get something way better on the steam store. You're better off buying doom or something. Seriously, don't buy this, go buy something else. Even if you're into goofy stuff, you're better off playing the game where you shower with your dad and a bunch of naked guys than this.PS: It also seems as if there is an issue with mouses for this game, so if you plan on playing this on a laptop or with certain types of mouses you won't be able to grab an item and lower the hand at the same time which is pretty necessary to complete ANY of the operations, so be ready to potentially have to buy a wired mouse because of this one game.

												This game seems really awesome because of how much control you have in controlling the hand and fingers, however once you actually start dealing with collision the items in your hands do odd behavior and go out of control. Its complete crap and people just struggle even getting past the first level.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2014
												This is brilliant! You take the role as a.. Let's say, not-so-well skilled doctor. By that i mean, you'll be put into a surgery where you have to do, let's say a heart transplant. The controls are a, w, e, r, space and mouse. Just like a real hand. Sounds easy? No.. It's not.. That's the thing about this game. It's really difficult to control the hand, and that makes it indeed funny.I totally recommend this game! The only cons would be, that it lacks different types of scenarios. (There's heart transplant, kidney transplant and brain transplant with a few different modes). And you really have to be careful about blood-loss, but that's the fun part too.As i said.. I recommend it, and you should already be buying it right now!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 10, 2013
												Surgeon Simulator is definitely an "experience". Most will likely find this game rather shallow and pointless, but as-it-is can be quite fun. I personally came into very skeptical but once booted I realized time had flown by and I was hooked messing around in someones body as chunks, bones, and tools went flying aroudn the roomMy biggest frustration didn't reside with the completely intentionally absurd controls, but with the total lack of instruction of what to do next to perform a "surgery". Even passing the first surgery was a struggle only because it wasn't clear what was needed to be done. Maybe this was intentional, but on top of the wacky control system, this added an unneccesarry challenge I believe.This will definetly not be a game for everyone, but if you have spare time and want to try something way out of left field, it can be worth a go for a bit. Don't expect it to be a long term satisfying game though.
